title: Swedish intern drops claims against former Wall Street boss
story: In 2015, Hanna Bouveng (left), 28, accused Wall Street executive Benjamin Wey (right) in an $850 million lawsuit of using his power to coerce her into four sexual encounters before firing her. On June 13, Bouveng, who was raised in Vetlanda, Sweden, filed court documents withdrawing and dismissing the claims against Wey without prejudiceBouveng and her lawyers dropped the lawsuit after Wey filed a counterclaim against the Swedish 28-year-old.Since the case was still in the appeal process,  Bouveng had yet to receive the $5.65 million that Wey was ordered to pay her. It comes three years after Bouveng filed an $850million lawsuit against her former employer, claiming he relentlessly harassed her after hiring her as a marketing intern at the company in 2013.She testified that soon after Wey hired her at New York Global Group, the CEO began a relentless quest to have sex with her.She claimed he pressured her into having sex with him on four occasions, but she had kept it a secret out of shame and fear that he was going to revoke her visa.She was fired from the company in 2014 after her boss walked in on her boyfriend lying in her bed in the $3,365-a-month Manhattan apartment Wey had rented for her.Wey also sought to defame Bouveng by posting articles on his blog accusing her of being a street walker, a loose woman and an extortionist, her lawyers said in the suit.          In 2015, Wey, 46, was ordered to pay Bouveng $5.65million in punitive damages on sexual harassment, retaliation and defamation claims. Bouveng was pictured smiling as she walked out of court following the rulingWey also emailed Bouveng's father after finding her in bed with another man, according to the New York Post.The message read: 'I saw a six-foot-tall homeless black man named James lying on her bed.'She said during the trial that she feared what Wey would do next after he 'started to harass and stalk me and my family and friends'.She added: 'I don't want to be in the US right now because I don't know what he's going to do and I feel safer in Sweden.'Wey has denied having sex with Bouveng, and his lawyers call her lawsuit 'extortion'.The married financier portrayed her as an opportunist who bragged that her grandfather was the billionaire founder of an aluminum company when Wey first met her in the Hamptons in July 2013.Wey testified that Bouveng knew nothing about finance before he hired and began mentoring her. He claimed she betrayed his generosity by embracing a party-girl lifestyle that left her too exhausted to succeed.Wey's wife, Michaela, broke down in tears as she was questioned about the alleged affair in court.          A year after the trial ended, Bouveng accused Wey of publishing negative comments about her online, breaching their agreement          Their court ordered agreement said that Wey would have to pay Bouveng $10,000 for every negative tweet he published about her, and $50,000 for each time he tried to communicate with her, The New York Post reportedIn an exclusive interview with The Post days after the verdict, Bouveng branded Wey a 'psychopath' who tried to 'control and isolate her'.'He manipulated me, and he broke me down in various different ways. It could be the way he was acting in the office, depending on whether I had dinner with him or not,' she said at the time.A year after the trial ended, Bouveng accused Wey of publishing negative comments about her online, breaching their agreement.Their court-ordered agreement said that Wey would have to pay Bouveng $10,000 for every negative tweet he published about her, and $50,000 for each time he tried to communicate with her, The New York Post reported.Bouveng claimed that Wey has violated the agreement dozens of times.Wey slammed Bouveng on Twitter as a 'homewrecker', 'cocaine user' and 'failed extortionist', according to court papers filed in Manhattan federal court in 2016Bouveng's lawyers claimed that 59 posts violated the $10,000 twitter agreement.Of those tweets, 26 also allegedly breached the $50,000 stipulation, which brings the fine to $1.3 million.A further $510,000 was sought based on other posts, bringing the total to $2.4 million.

title: Your unwanted clothes valuable earth going on
story: Help or hindrance: Academics say donations can restrict new retail economies in developing economies. Stock pictureThe price rag dealers pay for used clothes has climbed from about £220 a tonne in 2007 to about £500 a tonne today — and it’s an industry now worth £140 million.And rather than being unpicked and rewoven, as you might imagine, around half of old clothes you take to a charity shop or retailer are actually sold on — mainly in Eastern Europe and Africa.John Lewis says this is the case with its scheme: the bought-back clothes will either be resold or recycled, but the trial is at too early a stage to give expected percentages in each case.What’s more, charities say donations are falling in the face of this High Street competition, and that criminals are also being drawn to the high prices — there’s reports of donations being stolen.Many firms have sprung up offering to collect clothes door-to-door for free. Shipping them off to be sold isn’t the end of it, though.Alan Wheeler, director of the Textile Recycling Association, says: ‘Just because a retailer collects garments doesn’t mean the problem is solved. Where do they go?‘Typically clothes go through a sorting programme and maybe 50 per cent will be sold for export.‘The rest will need to be recycled: sometimes they are cut for wiping cloths, depending on the material, or they are used to manufacture heat and sound insulation or filling materials such as mattress or duvet fillings.‘Some textiles are used to make “shoddy”, a wool-substitute yarn which can make blankets used in relief work. Recycled fibres can also be used to manufacture the interior linings in cars.‘Even if the used clothing is of good enough quality to be reused, eventually it will wear out and have to be either recycled or disposed of.‘Of course, it would be much better to be able to recycle these worn out items, so it would be good if new garments were designed with recycling in mind.’And in terms of the plastics used in clothes, controversially Wheeler says that if the public turned against polyster in favour of cotton, it would only be swapping one big environmental problem for another.          India Sturgis with the clothes mountain at the Oxfam Wastewise recycling centre in Batley, West Yorkshire Conventional cotton production can cause huge environmental problems. It typically takes 20,000 litres of water to produce just one kilogram of cotton.Polyester — a synthetic man-made polymer and mostly non-biodegradable plastic — is used in 60 per cent of our garments. The most common is polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, which is the same plastic used in soft drink and ketchup bottles.In many respects, polyester’s popularity is a no-brainer. It’s cheap, lightweight, shape-retaining, easy to blend with other materials and long-lasting. Manufacturing techniques have become so sophisticated that it can now be spun finer than a human hair.Forget the rough, thick polyester shirts of old — some modern polyesters rival even the most expensive natural fibres in quality.Polyester or otherwise, what’s the best way to recycle your clothes?The new app reGAIN might offer consumers something different to the High Street take-back schemes. The idea is simple — choose a minimum of ten items to package in a cardboard box and use the app to locate your closest drop-off point.You receive a discount code from the partner of your choice to go towards your next purchase. Above all, Wheeler prefers the good old-fashioned method of taking clothes to the local charity shop — where the money they raise will go to good causes.But what happens to your bag of old clothes once you drop it off?Most of us do not appreciate what a massive and sophisticated operation lies behind your humble, High Street charity shop.I paid a visit to Oxfam’s colossal clothing sorting centre, a 90,000 sq ft former bed-making factory — bigger than a football pitch — on the fringes of Batley in Yorkshire, to find out.Here any excess clothing from its charity shops is sorted — and the complexity of dealing with our fast fashion habit is clear.On the morning I visit, the deliveries are rolling in. Endless steel conveyor belts send streams of black bin bags to workers who sort their contents by hand.Out come Hobbs dresses, M&ampS cashmere cardigans, babies’ bibs, and old shirts and suits, which are flung into industrial wheelie bins for compressing and packing.The walls heave with hay-bale-sized bags of clothes stacked against them and there’s a smell of musty attic fibres in the air.Some 17 tonnes of clothing a day are sorted here. More than half is sent to Frip Ethique, the charity’s social enterprise project in Senegal providing work for 40 local men and women and stock for market traders. A large chunk of heavy-duty winter garments heads off to be commercially resold in Eastern Europe.Oxfam global ambassador Annie Lennox breaks her silence to...Halfords apologises for selling 'His and Hers' key rings...The must-have toys for Christmas... 200 days early!  2018...'I have been deeply concerned about our country': Starbucks'...Share this articleIf it can’t be worn again — the case in around a tenth of donations — it’s sold to recycling companies for industrial use as rags or mattress stuffing. Nothing — not one sock — gets sent to landfill.If items are too damp or dirty to process — around a minuscule 2 per cent of overall donations — they’re incinerated locally to produce energy for 400 Yorkshire homes.Despite this ingenuity, Lorraine Needham-Reid, the site’s manager of production, is still concerned about our wasteful attitude.‘I’m absolutely stunned by what people throw away,’ she says. ‘We see brand new items sent here, never worn, with tags still in. It is scary what people chuck out.’So what of the clothes we send to council recycling banks that are found on urban streets or in supermarket car parks?Sixty per cent is exported overseas for resale in second-hand clothing markets to countries such as Poland, Lithuania, Benin, Ghana and Togo.But this troubles Dr Andy Brooks, a lecturer in development geography at King’s College and author of Clothing Poverty, a book about fast fashion and the second-hand clothing sector.‘People think their old clothes are most likely to be sold in a local charity shop,’ he says. ‘However, there is a large international trade in used clothing that’s hidden from view.’‘Poor countries have had their markets flooded by second-hand garments.‘Factories in African countries including Ghana and Zambia have had to close down because they are uncompetitive.‘In the short term, cheap used clothing seems to be good for poor African consumers, but in the long term it harms their balance of trade and restricts industrial development.’So if recycling overseas is problematic when not overseen by an organisation such as Oxfam, and landfills equally so, could a beacon of hope be ‘fibre-to-fibre chemical recycling’ — essentially, making new garments out of old synthetic ones?Scientists have yet to find a workable method to magic synthetic clothing into new apparel — but the best attempt has so far come from outdoor clothing specialists Patagonia, who use PET clear plastic drinks bottles to make jackets, shorts and fleeces.But there are problems with taking that to the next stage, says Alan Wheeler.‘With polyester clothing you’ve got different dyes, you might have cotton threads within the item, it might have a nylon lining. Every item is different. Chemical recycling processes are looking at how to change all different polyester clothing into one homogenous product that can then be recycled easily.’ A move towards a circular clothing economy is something a few industry leaders are beginning to tentatively work towards.‘We need to slow down the amount we produce and encourage people to keep and use their clothes for longer,’ says Wheeler.‘The whole notion that celebrities and royals like the Duchess of Cambridge are radically “recycling” clothes when they’re spotted wearing the same item more than once is very frustrating. It should be considered normal practice,’ he adds.Wheeler points to the ‘elephant in the room’ when it comes to recycling and clothing retailers. ‘It is difficult for them to be sustainable because their survival is dependent on us buying more and more clothes,’ he says.‘I would argue that they need to encourage the public to buy less, pay more (that way they would pay their workers more, too) and design items that are made to last.’Currently consumer pressure for new garments means companies produce clothes faster to lower standards — which are then less able to withstand repeat wear.According to a recent report from WRAP, the average piece of clothing in the UK lasts for 3.3 years before being discarded.Other research puts the life of UK garments at 2.2 years.For a younger demographic, you can probably halve that. But the experts want us to do better than that.So it’s a case of step away from the shopping basket (literally or virtually), rewear what you already own, and recycle those you don’t — this way you save the planet as well as your pennies.

title: Zigzag sawfly Japan eating elm trees UK Zorro shaped mark
story: The zigzag elm sawfly, originally found in Japan, feeds only on elm leaves and has been progressing steadily through Europe. It lives a zigzag white mark on its leaves (pictured) and has now been found in the UK Elm leaf-feeding insects such as the rare white-letter hairstreak butterfly, which suffered in the 1970s due to the loss of trees to Dutch elm disease, could be hit by the new pest's arrival.While the zigzag elm sawfly rarely kills trees, large populations can completely defoliate elms, which could be disastrous for the white-letter hairstreak whose populations are sometimes restricted to single trees, the experts said.The first evidence of the pest in Britain was a chance discovery, according to scientists at RBGE.RBGE mycologist Dr Katherine Hayden said: 'Plant samples arrived here to be identified as part of local plant recording activity carried out by experienced amateurs in Surrey.Farewell Koko, the gorilla who proved animals CAN talk to us...Thousands pack Stonehenge to witness sunrise on the summer...Share this article'Examination by our elm specialist revealed the curious zigzag feeding damage as the first evidence of the pest in Britain.'RBGE science communicator Max Coleman said: 'The zigzag elm sawfly can quickly build up pest populations as females are able to reproduce asexually.'People will be familiar with how fast greenfly can spread. The sawfly has evolved the same strategy: exploit the speed advantage of asexual reproduction and avoid the risk of not finding a mate.'Scientists are now asking people to report sightings of the unmistakable zigzag pattern, to track the sawfly's spread and help scientists secure definitive evidence of its presence in the form of adult insects, larvae or pupae.It has also prompted renewed calls for action to protect the UK's woodlands and wildlife.          The discovery has raised concerns it could pose another blow to the UK's elms, which have already been devastated by Dutch elm disease, and threaten wildlife that rely on the treesDr Nick Atkinson, senior conservation advisor for the Woodland Trust, said: 'This could be another blow to the elm population, following the widespread devastation caused by Dutch elm disease, which began in the 1970s and continues even today.'By continuing to allow the import of trees and other living materials we are risking the health of our natural landscapes and our own well-being as a consequence.'Action is needed now. Government, with buy-in from the forestry and horticulture sectors, and even supermarkets that sell plants, need to help minimise further risks to our native trees and woodlands.'The zigzag elm sawfly rarely kills elm trees alone but rids them of their leaves, which are needed for photosynthesis.This makes them far more vulnerable to being killed by other problems such as Dutch elm disease, which still exists in Britain. Because of Dutch elm disease, many of the surviving elm trees in Britain are young, which puts them at greater risk from the sawfly.At the last count in the 1990s, there were estimated to be roughly five million elm trees in Britain.

title: Darling Buds house owned author Bates goes sale 1 1m
story: This Kent country house, which inspired both the book and TV show of The Darling Buds of May, is on sale for the first time in 90 years - for £1.1million  Author HE Bates lived in The Granary in the village of Little Chart for more than 40 years and used the surroundings as inspiration for the stories of Pop Larkin and his family. Above, the cast of the show, including David Jason (left, as Pop Larkin centre Catherine Zeta Jones, as his daughter Mariette and next to her, Philip Franks playing her husband, Charley)          The Granary was just an agricultural building when Herbert Ernest Bates and his wife Madge bought it in 1931. At the time, the ground floor was open to the elements and there was still straw and grain upstairs. They spent £600 converting it into a home          The house has 2,950 sq ft of accommodation with a large hall, sitting room, dining room, drawing room, kitchenbreakfast room, a master bedroom with a dressing room and en suite bathroom, three further bedrooms and a family bathroom          As well as writing his novels in the house, Bates re-formed the village's cricket club in the 1960s and became the chairman          After HE Bates's death in 1974, his widow sold the house directly to the Gizzi family and this is the first time it has been on the open market, and it is now being sold by their son Julien GizziRichard used the village green outside The Granary to film many of the scenes with David Jason, who played Pop Larkin (whose catchphrase was 'perfick'), along with Catherine Zeta Jones, Pam Ferris and the rest of the cast.Other scenes were shot in the neighbouring village of Pluckley and the Larkin's farm was Buss Farm in Bethersden.The show launched in 1991, with Zeta Jones playing Pa Larkin's eldest daughter, Mariette - in a role that helped launch her stellar career. The series became a huge success and was also the first programme to be broadcast - at 4pm - after ITV's coverage of the funeral of Princess Diana in 1997.          Richard used the village green outside The Granary to film many of the scenes with David Jason (Pop Larkin's catchphrase was 'perfick'), along with Catherine Zeta Jones, Pam Ferris and the rest of the cast          The idea for Pop Larkin came from a colourful character Bates saw in the local shop who turned up with a wad of rubber-banded bank notes and spoiled his trailer-load of children with ice creams. HE Bates (pictured at the property) was a keen gardener          Pictured, HE Bates relaxes outside the house. After he died, his TV producer son Richard acquired the rights for the Darling Buds of May TV adaptation of the 1958 novel          Both the house and garden are in immaculate order, having been maintained by a housekeeper and gardenerThe Granary was just an agricultural building when Herbert Ernest Bates and his wife Madge bought it in 1931.At the time, the ground floor was open to the elements and there was still straw and grain upstairs. Catherine Zeta Jones during her Darling Buds era. Some scenes for the show were shot in the neighbouring village of Pluckley and the Larkin's farm was Buss Farm in Bethersden          The Darling Buds of May launched in 1991, with Zeta Jones playing Pa Larkin's eldest daughter, Mariette - in a role that helped launch her stellar career. The series became a huge success and was also the first programme to air - at 4pm - after ITV's coverage of the funeral of Princess Diana in 1997. Ma Larkin (also next to Jason) was played by Pam Ferris      H.E. Bates (Herbert Ernest Bates) was born in Rushden, Northamptonshire, in 1905.After grammar school, he joined the Northampton Chronicle at the age of 16 but realised it wasn't for him and left two months later.A two-year stint as a factory clerk followed, and then he began writing in earnest. His first novel was The Two Sisters - which led to him being fired from the factory when his boss found him working on it in company time.It was eventually published in 1926. Other shorts stories and novels would follow - many focusing on his love for the countryside.During the Second World War, he achieved acclaim after being commissioned to write stories for the RAF - including How Sleep the Brave (1943) and Fair Stood the Wind for France (1944).He would go on to write The Darling Buds of May in 1958, featuring the loveable Larkin family.The first part of his autobiography, The Vanished World, was published in 1969, and part two, The Blossoming World, in 1971 - three years before his death.                                                    Simon Backhouse, from Strutt &amp Parker, said: 'This is completely Darling Buds of May country.'You turn onto a little lane that takes you down into this beautiful village green and all around it are half a dozen really beautiful houses, one of which is The Granary.'It's beautifully done and you feel like you're walking into a 1950s' novel, a little bit like a time capsule.'It's a lifestyle property for someone looking to escape to the country. 'If you are into that sort of bucolic country living, roses round the door and that sort of thing, this is the perfect property.'It's an old-fashioned country living, make jam in the kitchen, kind of home.'The fact that it has only been owned by two families shows the quality of the house.'           'It's beautifully done and you feel like you're walking into a 1950s' novel, a little bit like a time capsule,' said Simon Backhouse, from Strutt &amp Parker          The house sits in about half an acre of grounds, which were laid out and landscaped by Bates as a series of 'rooms' with pathways, colourful flower beds and a variety of focal points  Above, an article about HE Bates and his love of gardening, soon after he had published the second volume of his autobiography, The Blossoming World, in 1971. The piece focused on his home, in the Kentish Weald          The garden also  has an oak pergola covered in climbing roses and a garden roomsummer house which has power and heating

title: Never seen photos Prince Andrew Navy initiation ceremony
story: Photos have emerged of Prince Andrew's 'crossing the line' initiation ceremony in the Royal Navy, which took place the first time he passed the equator as a seaman in 1982          Andrew, dressed in a novelty crown, was sat on a thrown like chair and brought before a staged up court on the deck of the HMS Invincible  Failure sailors, dressed as old-fashioned police officers, bundled him into his chair before Nepture, God of the sea, tried him           At the end of the initiation ceremony, he was gunged, to the glee of sailors looking onFor king and country! Riders charge through town to mark...Horror at Royal Ascot as racegoers travelling to Ladies Day...All partied out! Ascot revellers are left a little the worse...Share this article    The images show Andrew being carried into the 'court' before his 'trial' before Neptune began          The photos, taken on the aircraft carrier's deck after the Falklands, show the arrival of Neptune          Another sailor dressed as Neptune oversaw the ceremony before the Prince was 'shaved'          Andrew was brought before the court by sailors dressed in old-fashioned police uniforms          The pictures, which include one of Andrew being interviewed for Forces Radio, were taken by another crew member on board the warship and sent to two autograph-hunting children  HMS Invincible's Admiral Jeremy Black took part in the ceremony. The pictures also document the Falklands War, with one of the Harriers which helped win the conflict seen being transported by a Chinook helicopter          The photos also shown the remains of Argentinian jets in Port Stanley on the Falklands Islands          A Sea King helicopter and its crew are also seen off the side of the HMS InvincibleOther pictures in the gallery include Andrew in uniform being interviewed, shots of the deck of the ship and one of a Chinook helicopter lifting Sea Harrier jet.During the Falklands War, Prince Andrew risked his life by acting as a decoy to lure Argentine Exocet missiles away from HMS Invincible.He flew a Navy helicopter behind the aircraft carrier to make the missiles swerve towards the helicopter instead of the ship. He also flew on anti-submarine missions and search and rescue operations.The archive is tipped to sell for £200 at Bosleys on July 4.

title: Woman left unable open mouth witch doctor brands tongue
story: Jatha Devi, 25, from Pali in Rajasthan, had been unwell for some time but when her condition did not improve in hospital her relatives forced her to see a witch doctor Her parents Bhanwar Lal and Sanjini Devi, also labourers, took Jatha to witch doctor Jairam Bhat on Sunday. During the 'treatment' the sham doctor mercilessly branded her lips, tongue, forehead and arms for two days with a hot trident.Jatha's condition worsened as she was unable to utter a word and was whimpering with acute pain.Five women working for a Christian missionary aid charity...Every parent's worst nightmare: Girl, six, is led away to be...Share this articleShe was immediately rushed to Bangar Hospital in Jodhpur where doctors attending her found her to be suffering from a mental illness - acute psychosis.Dr Daljeet Singh Ranawat, consultant psychiatrist at the hospital, said: 'Jatha is suffering from acute psychosis, a condition in which the patient has hallucinations and jumbled speech, anxiety, confusion and insomnia.'Luckily, it is curable and the treatment lasts no longer than six months.  Jatha's condition got worse rather than better and she was found to have acute psychosis

title: Raab Britain not cower corner Brexit negotiations EU
story: A no deal Brexit is becoming more likely because there is still no deal on Northern Ireland, Leo Vardkar (pictured today in Guernsey) has warnedA no deal Brexit is becoming more likely because there is still no deal on Northern Ireland, Leo Vardkar warned today after meeting the UK and Scottish governments. The Irish premier said the risks of a collapse in the negotiations was more likely than a few months ago just days before the next EU summit.Mr Varadkar hit out at the failure to make progress after meeting Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington at the British-Irish Council in Guernsey. His intervention comes after a senior Brexiteer minister demanded his colleagues be more positive in the talks.Vote Leave veteran Dominic Raab said Britain must not 'cower in the corner' during negotiations in Brussels. Mr Varadkar said: 'I think it is more likely than it was a few months ago but I still don't think it is likely.'Ultimately it is in the interests of Ireland and in the interests of the United Kingdom and the interests of the European Union that we have an orderly Brexit and a new relationship that works for everyone.'PM scrambles to defuse business fury over Brexit after...Boris Johnson WILL miss crunch vote on expanding Heathrow by...Share this articleThe Taoiseach said talks to find a resolution would 'intensify' over the next couple of months.'That's what we are going to do over the next couple of months, really try to intensify our efforts to come to a withdrawal agreement,' he said.Mr Varadkar said there could only be a withdrawal agreement if there was a backstop for the Irish border in it.          Mr Varadkar hit out at the failure to make progress after meeting Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington at the British-Irish Council in Guernsey (he is pictured arriving at today's talks He added: 'To be a backstop it needs to solve the problem. It needs to deal with customs and regulatory issues and it needs not to have an expiry date because the whole point of a backstop is that it doesn't have an expiry date.'But it is also important to recognise that it is not something we ever want to have to use.'On the eve of the second anniversary of the referendum Mr Raab said his colleagues in Government must come up with an 'aspirational message' about the opportunities of Brexit and resist allowing the 'din of criticism' to dominate discussions.Chancellor Philip Hammond has been a target of Brexiteer criticism for being too pessimistic - prompting him to use his Mansion House speech last night to deny the Treasury was trying to promote Remain.           Britain is at risk of looking afraid of its own shadow in Brexit talks,  senior Brexiteer minister  Dominic Raab (file) warned today          Chancellor Philip Hammond has been a target of Brexiteer criticism for being too pessimistic - prompting him to use his Mansion House speech last night (pictured) to deny the Treasury was trying to promote Remain.Housing Minister Mr Raab said that while there were risks in quitting the bloc which should be acknowledge there were opportunities that must be grasped.He told The House magazine: 'We need to manage the risks, and I've talked about some of them with the implementation period, but we also need to be confident about grasping the opportunities.'I think we should go into these negotiations with a bit of economic self-confidence.'The economy has held up and proved far more resilient than some of the naysayers suggested. We should go into it with political ambition. So, yes, mitigate the risks but we should grasp the opportunities.'One thing I get nervous about, or anxious, is that we don't cower in a corner so fixated on the risk that we look somehow afraid of our own shadow. Britain is a hell of a lot better than that.'          Airbus chief operating officer Tom Williams made the dire warning of potential job losses in the event of a no-deal BrexitMr Raab said the government and the country must 'show that we are bigger than the sum of our parts'.'We need to really make sure that we come up with that aspirational message, we are talking about the tangible opportunities, and do not allow the din of criticism to swallow up the debate,' he added.The two year anniversary was overshadowed today as Airbus became the first major manufacturer to confirm it had contingency plans to pull out of Britain.  The firm employs 14,000 people at 25 sites across the country - including Bristol, Portsmouth and north Wales - but 110,000 jobs would also be at risk at companies supplying the European aircraft maker.Airbus, which generates £1.7billion in tax revenues, said it would 'reconsider its investments in the UK, and its long-term footprint in the country' if Britain left the single market and customs union without a transition agreement.An Airbus employee at the firm's Filton plant in Bristol works on the tailfin of an A440M in this file photoIt is one of the most significant interventions by a major company since the 2016 EU referendum, and would see Airbus become the first big manufacturer to pull investment from the UK in the wake of Theresa May's stalled Brexit negotiations.Publishing a Brexit 'risk assessment' on its website, the firm also called on the Government to extend the planned transition period due to run until December 2020 if a deal is agreed, saying it was too short for the business to reorganise its supply chain.If there was no extension it would 'carefully monitor any new investments in the UK and refrain from extending the UK supplierspartners base', it said.Tory MP Stephen Crabb said the warning from Airbus should be a 'wake-up call

title: Huge rise breeding cartoon face designer horses slammed vet
story: A horse called Jewel, who has been selectively bred, showing bulging eyes  A selectively bred horses teeth poking out of its mouth because there is no space in its mouth (left) and (right) an x-ray of a selectively bred horse's mouth with circles showing the gap where teeth have been unable to break through due to overcrowding (red) and teeth that have broken (green)Miss Fowler, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, sees at least one suffering animal every week for problems caused by 'cartoon' faces. She said: 'Humans have decided that some breeds look 'pretty' like this, but they haven't considering the resulting pony's ability to breathe or how their teeth are going to fit in their mouths.'These designer horses are sometimes referred to as 'Disney' horses because they look like cartoons with their pulled-in noses and popping-out eyes.'If it continues to get more extreme ponies may well face the problem of their eyes popping out as is common in brachycephalic dog breeds.'Over the last couple of years I'd say it's become particularly bad with the Arabs, miniatures and Welsh Section As.'          Miss Fowler (pictured with miniature horse Heathcliffe) sees at least one suffering animal every week for problems caused by 'cartoon' faces          Juno (pictured) is Jewel's mum who is not selectively bredHorror at Royal Ascot as racegoers travelling to Ladies Day...Racing cyclist 'smashes into a horse and then flips his...The horses bred to have cartoon faces: Vets' horror at...Share this articleMiss Fowler regularly sees ponies with health problems resulting from breeding for 'prettiness'.She says shrinking horses' noses causes a massive problem for their mouths as their teeth can't fit properly.The consequences can be dire to the horse's life , shrinking it considerably and tragically in most cases horse owners are not aware of the health issues faced by their pets.Despite owners sometimes splashing thousands of pounds to own one they often have to face the pain of putting a horse through risky surgery or putting them to sleep because the animals' quality of life is so poor.          The designer horses are sometimes referred to as 'Disney' horses, because they look like animals from the cartoons (pictured) with their pulled-in noses and popping-out eyes          Miss Fowler examining a horse's mouth at work in WiganIn October last year an Arabian show horse called El Rey Magnum was born in the US, and left experts horrified because of its concave face.The owners of the nine month old colt was said to resemble cartoon horses in Disney films Sleeping Beauty and Aladdin.Miss Fowler said: 'People seem to like these very dainty, pulled-in faces but that gives them breathing difficulties and dental problems. I'm seeing these deformities on a weekly basis.'One problem is there isn't enough space for their teeth because their mouths are smaller.          In October last year it emerged an Arabian show horse called El Rey Magnum (pictured) was born in the US, and left experts horrified because of its concave face          Example of extreme breeding, more usually seen in cats and dogs, can often be seen in the Arabian horse pedigree like Apalo, pictured, grandfather to El Rey Magnum'As a result the teeth grow everywhere and, in some cases, they'll make a whole space of their own behind the oral cavity because they can't fit in their mouths.'The x-ray from a horse I recently treated shows clearly that her teeth can't fit properly.'One is sitting behind her oral cavity, another has twisted 90 degrees because it wouldn't fit.'While human teeth are simple to extract, horse teeth can be anything from 8cm to 15cm long depending on the size of the horse. To extract a horse's tooth requires very big surgery.'One pony I recently treated is not expected to live very long at all now and she's only six. Selective breeding can certainly decrease life expectancy.'          Pedigree horses bred to have a concave face, pictured, has been described as ‘horrific’ by veterinary experts.Aside from the difficult situation of seeing their horse in pain, owners are often faced with bills reaching into the thousands due to the complexity of surgery.If surgery is needed it can be intense and 'massively risky' if the horse needs anaesthetic.Miss Fowler, who owns three horses herself, said: 'If a horse needs an operation the vet bills can be in the thousands. It is a much more serious procedure for horses than humans.'Ethically vets have to decide what is best for the horse because surgery is massively invasive.'Most owners decide they don't want to put their horses through it.'Horses have a one in 100 chance of death from general anaesthetic, compared with humans who have a one in 100,000 chance.'Any surgery is massively risky. It's very, very intense.'She claims it is often a horse's failure to show pain, as it is taught in the wild, that means owners are oblivious to the level of pain or suffering they are going through.As a result, it can already be too late by the time they visit the vet.'Usually the owners don't know their horses are in pain. Horses are prey animals - they don't show pain,' she said.'It's astonishing how severe the problems can get before the horses show any signs of pain or weight loss.'Pain is weakness in the wild and they would get eaten so often the problems are found when it is much too late to help the animal.'When found early, the owners are very surprised to find their animal is in pain.'The practice owner has now urged breeders to be more responsible, calling on them to consider functionality and what is best for the horse.Miss Fowler added: 'I think the focus needs to be on breeders as well as owners or buyers.'The breeders pushing for the extreme features that are causing the health issues are certainly irresponsible.'They breed for profit and create horses wanted for being pretty as opposed to functioning or healthy. That's the main source of the problem and it's definitely getting worse.'But while dogs can live on a soft diet without teeth if need be, horses need to eat grass for up to 20 hours a day.'People need to consider functionality and what is best for the horse. This is a massive problem in the horse world.'

title: Historic 20 sided stone fort built Royal Marines base 16ft deep moat sale
story: A historic fort in Pembroke Dock, Wales,  is up for sale for £1.2m as the ultimate 'fixer-upper' - complete with a 16ft-deep moat          One section of the historic fort has already been turned into these large flats which have a homely feel to themThe Grade-II listed building is thought to be the last example of a square Bastian trace fortification in Europe.London¿s ¿Cheesegrater¿ tower, Tate St Ives and a touching...A house that's just Perfick! Countryside home where HE Bates...Gardener wins £3MILLION on Lotto scratchcard thanks to a...Share this articleBastion forts emerged during as the cannon became a pivotal force in the battlefield, and the design was first seen in 15th century Italy. They are usually designed in the shape of a pentagon or hexagon, with bastions in the corner (allowing fire in multiple directions).           The 20-sided fort,  named The Defensible Barracks, was built for the British military more than 150 years ago          A spokesperson for Purple Bricks said: 'Planning permission has been granted for a 56-bedroom hotel and even a coffee shop'          It is rumoured that the huge Welsh fort was completed in just one year, according to author Phil Carradice for the BBCIt is rumoured that the huge Welsh fort was completed in just one year, according to author Phil Carradice in a blog for the BBC.However, others claim that the building work on the £75,000 project began in 1841 and finished in 1846. The first occupants of the newly built barracks were the Royal Marines of the Portsmouth Division, followed by companies from the West Yorkshire Regiment.          The homes built in the impressive barracks are cosy, and from the inside you would never know it had previously been a military base          The first occupants of the newly built barracks were the Royal Marines of the Portsmouth Division, followed by companies from the West Yorkshire Regiment          The property is located in Pembroke, Wales, with stunning countryside scenery making it the perfect spot to relax          During the First World War, the fort was a siege training school for the Royal Artillerymen, and in the Second World War it was used as the Milford Haven headquarters, until coast defences were abolishedFollowing this, the Pembrokeshire Artillery, the Royal North Gloucestershire Regiment and the South Wales Borderers stayed at the barracks, with soldiers eventually leaving the fort in the 1960s.The impressive fort housed 16 cannons to defend the dockyard from an attack, and had almost 700 rifle loops.A cannon was fired twice a day at 12pm and 9.30pm, to let residents without watches know what time it was, and to inform young girls of their curfew.           The converted apartments make for a lovely home, with this modern design feeling a million miles away from its historical roots          The impressive fort housed 16 cannons to defend the dockyard from an attack, and had almost 700 rifle loops          Famous residents of the barracks include Gordon of Khartoum, who was later deployed to join the fighting in Crimea, and Arthur Lowe, who played Captain Mainwaring in Dad's ArmyDespite the barracks being built to protect, it was the source of devastation in 1942 when soldiers trained to disarm mines - resulting in 19 of them dying.Famous residents of the barracks include Gordon of Khartoum, who was later deployed to join the fighting in Crimea, and Arthur Lowe, who played Captain Mainwaring in Dad's Army.During the First World War, the fort was a siege training school for the Royal Artillerymen, and in the Second World War it was used as the Milford Haven headquarters, until coast defences were abolished.          Buyers hoping to snap up the slice of history should contact Ross McKenzie from Purplebricks estate agents          During the First World War, the fort was a siege training school for the Royal Artillerymen, and in the Second World War it was used as the Milford Haven headquarters, until coast defences were abolishedBuyers hoping to snap up the slice of history should contact Ross McKenzie from Purplebricks estate agents.A spokesman said: 'One section of the impressive structure has already been converted into apartments - and the remainder is derelict.'But planning permission has been granted for a 56-bedroom hotel and even a coffee shop.'          The fort is entered through a north gatehouse complete with holes for muskets and winches for the former sliding drawbridge          Bastion forts emerged during as the cannon became a pivotal force in the battlefield, and the design was first seen in 15th century Italy          They are usually designed in the shape of a pentagon or hexagon, with bastions in the corner (allowing fire in multiple directions)          Following the Second World War, the fort was sold to South Pembrokeshire council and was then sold on in 1987The fort is entered through a north gatehouse complete with holes for muskets and winches for the former sliding drawbridge.There is a 140 foot central parade ground surrounded by a quad shaped two-storey building.Following the Second World War, the fort was sold to South Pembrokeshire council and was then sold on in 1987.

title: Swedish reporter covering World Cup grabbed kissed live air
story: Malin Wahlberg had to fend off a Swedish fan who draped his arms around her back and kissed her during a broadcast in Nizhny Novgorod   Despite having her hair ruffled and the distraction of boisterous Swedish fans bouncing in the background she carried on professionally with the broadcastMs Wahlberg was presenting live coverage ahead of Sweden's fixture against South Korea when she was bothered by the travelling fans.The match was on Monday but the footage has surfaced after Colombian journalist Julieth Gonzalez Theran was harassed during a broadcast for Deutsche Welle. Earlier the Russian man who groped Ms Gonzalez Theran during a live broadcast apologised and said it was a 'misunderstanding' as he meant to touch her shoulder.The Colombian reporter was working for the German news channel in the Russian city of Saransk when the man came into shot, grabbed her breast and kissed her on the cheek. England's 2-1 triumph over Tunisia pulls in peak TV audience...'Wolves of the caliphate - get ready for hunting season':...Share this articleMs Gonzalez Theran bravely carried on presenting despite the harassment, but the man, named only as Ruslan, has offered his 'profound apologies'. He claimed he had a bet with friends that he could kiss a reporter live on air, and meant to put his hand on her shoulder but instead touched her breast by mistake.   He told the German broadcaster he had not picked on Ms Gonzales Theran for her age or gender but because she 'happened to be nearby'.  Attack: Julieth Gonzalez Theran was reporting from the World Cup in Saransk, Russia, when a man walked on camera, grabbed her breast and kissed her on the cheek          True professional: Despite being harassed and groped, Ms Gonzalez Theran kept on reporting to the camera

title: Late night hosts eviscerate Melania tone deaf jacket
story: 'But today, on her way to show that she cares, Melania wore a jacket that says, 'I REALLY DON'T CARE, DO U?''The Late Show host joked that a first lady visiting disadvantaged immigrant children, should have been a PR home run for the White House.Chorus of celebrities attack the First Lady over 'dumb and...Share this article'I thought, 'OK, this is what first ladies often do - you go to a troubled area, they see the children, they show that we care ... you can't mess that up.'''Guess what?' he added. 'I spoke too soon.'          Stephen Colbert said he and his team checked the photo 'so many times because we thought this has to be fakeColbert said that he was stunned that the people around Melania would allow her to get on Air Force One, in front of the world's media, with the offensive jacket.'That's what they settled on? What was her first choice? A jacket that says, 'Womp, womp?'' added Colbert, referring to a comment from Trump's former campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, who callously mocked an immigrant girl, 10, with Down syndrome who was separated from her mother at the border. Late Night's Seth Meyers also ripped into the jacket, suggesting that if the outer wear had any message, it could relate to Melania and Donald Trump's 'wedding vows.'    In the White House: The slogan was there for all to see as Melania made her way to the Oval Office - at almost the same time as her husband tweeted that it was a message for the 'Fake News Media', not immigrant children she had visited at the border  Shocking: The green Zara design featured the controversial phrase across the back - with the wording  visible from the side as Melania boarded her plane at Andrews Air Force Base          Defense: President Trump tweeted in response to the outcry on Thursday evening, stating that the message on his wife's jacket 'refers to the Fake News Media''You know, lot of people are giving her a hard time about it, but I think it's nice that she had a jacket made to display her wedding vows,' he joked.'You take this man to be your lawfully wedded husband?' 'I don't care. Do you?' 'No.' 'The Daily Show host Trevor Noah, who appeared to be at the end of his tether about the Trumps, said: 'It looks like when Melania was in the hospital, she had her last f**k removed.'He also echoed Mysers, joking: 'It is kind of sweet that she made a jacket out of her and Donald's wedding vows. That's really cool! I like that.' Melania's spokeswoman emphatically claimed after the media furor, that Melania hadn't been trying to send any message with her 'jacket seen round the world.'           The Daily Show host Trevor Noah, who appeared to be at the end of his tether about the Trumps, said: 'It looks like when Melania was in the hospital, she had her last f**k removed''It's just a jacket. ... There was no hidden message,' the said. The claim  was immediately undermined by the president who tweeted that it had beena commentary on the 'Fake News Media.'Colbert said he agreed with one point, the message is 'definitely not hidden.'  'It's right on the back. And i'm going to guess this is one message she did not steal from Michelle Obama,' he said, referring to claims that Melania plagiarized the former First Lady's speeches.'She's forgotten the most important fashion advice,' he added. 'Before you leave the house, look in the mirror, and take off that jacket.''Is the president now tweeting onto his wife's clothes?' Jimmy Kimmel asked on his show.          Meanwhile, Jimmy Fallon joked that maybe it wasn't Melania's jacket to begin with'There either was or wasn't a hidden message,' he said. 'It was one of those two things.'The host of Jimmy Kimmel Live also pointed out the hypocrisy of the right's fury when the Obamas chose to wear anything other than very formal, traditional attire.'Remember when Michelle Obama showed her bare arms and went to an oil spill, and Fox News went nuts? I'm sure they'll have the same reaction to this,' he added.Indeed, that happened. The right also lost its mind when President Obama wore a tan suit, with one Republican lawmaker even claiming that the choice of clothing put national security at risk.Meanwhile, Jimmy Fallon joked that maybe it wasn't Melania's jacket to begin with.'President Trump was going through his closet... where the hell is my coat, where is my favorite coat?'      It comes as Hollywood and beyond continued to express their outrage over Melania's callous jacket

title: Devon ghost watched boy riding bike turns security guard
story: Louise Lenton, 41, filmed her five-year-old son cycling round a carpark and spotted what she thought was a ghost (circled) watching on. He has now been revealed to be a 68-year-old security guard wearing a cardigan - and not a spooky Victorian woman as Ms Lenton thought          Alex Warren (above) came forward on a community Facebook group to announce that he was the ghost at the window of Oldway Mansion in Paignton, Devon - here he's even wearing similar clothing as seen on the video except for the cardiganMr Warren said: 'I wear my black cardigan inside and my security coat for outside patrols.'That day I was just admiring the young lad, learning to ride his bike. Hope this clears up the misunderstanding!Mother sees the 'ghostly face' of her miscarried child...Share this article'There are, to my knowledge - no ghosts at Oldway, and I have worked days and nights here for over four years.'Ms Lenton, of Paignton, shot the video of her son cycling in the car park at around 5pm on a recent Sunday.          Mr Warren said: 'I wear my black cardigan inside and my security coat for outside patrols. That day I was just admiring the young lad, learning to ride his bike. Hope this clears up the misunderstanding!'At around the 18-second mark, the shape of a person can be seen in the window.The figure was described as apparently a woman, wearing Victorian period dress.But Mr Warren's explanation tallies with the video, shot from some distance away from the window.Ms Lenton said at the time: 'My partner and I had split off, with him going to walk the dogs on the fields and I took our little boy to the car park to practise riding his bike.          'There are, to my knowledge - no ghosts at Oldway, and I have worked days and nights here for over four years,' said Mr Warren (pictured)'The car park is flat and perfect to do it. I was just filming him and that was it.'It wasn't until I was home and in bed watching the film back when I noticed it. I was like, Oh my gosh!' and my partner could not explain it. Neither of us know what this is.'When I was filming, I didn't see it at all. I was too busy filming. I screenshotted it and zoomed in straight away.'It looks like a lady with hair in a bun, with white cuffs around her hands..'The listed mansion was built at the end of the 19th century in the French Renaissance style for the Singer family, who made their fortune from producing sewing machines.

title: Armed Forces Day 2018 need know
story: Armed Forces Day gives communities the chance to support to the soldiers who are servingArmed Forces DayAfter replacing previous Veterans’ Day, Armed Forces Day was first observed in 2009 on the day after the anniversary of the first investiture ceremony for the Victoria Cross military medal for heroism, which was held on June 26, 1957.The celebrations were held at a former Royal Navy base, the Chatham Historic Dockyard, and Prime Minister Gordon Brown, his wife Sarah, Prince Richard, the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester were in attendance.Every year, a different city holds the national event, with celebrations taking place for a week with Armed Forces Day being held on the last Saturday each June.          The Red Arrows display during the sixth annual Armed Forces Day in Stirling, ScotlandWhen is Armed Forces Day 2018?Due to Armed Forces Day being held on the last Saturday of June every year, in 2018, it will take place on Saturday, June 30.Official celebrations will begin on Monday, June 25 with the Armed Forces flag being raised on buildings and famous landmarks around the country.In addition to this, Reserves Day will also provide an opportunity for communities to honour the Reserve Forces and this will take place on June 27, 2018.          A Pipe band parades during the sixth annual Armed Forces Day in Stirling, Scotland in 2014Where is the Armed Forces 2018 national event?The National Event for 2018 will be held in Llandudno, North Wales, but local events will be taking place across the UK. title: Woman celebrates dogs pregnancy new pups hilarious photo series
story: Nala (far left) and Simba (far right) with their Monkey, Mouse, Moose, Wolff and Panther          Once the puppies were born, owner Bec Panthers decided to take  some pictures of the adorable new arrivals           Bec said pug puppies are 'so adorable' and she was 'over the moon' when the litter arrived           She sought inspiration from pictures of newborn babies she found online to photograph the dogs           Nala as a hungry expectant mother and Simba as a nervous dad in this hilarious pregnancy announcement Bec said: 'I've always absolutely adored pugs. title: Your unwanted clothes valuable earth going on
story: Help or hindrance: Academics say donations can restrict new retail economies in developing economies. Stock pictureThe price rag dealers pay for used clothes has climbed from about £220 a tonne in 2007 to about £500 a tonne today — and it’s an industry now worth £140 million.And rather than being unpicked and rewoven, as you might imagine, around half of old clothes you take to a charity shop or retailer are actually sold on — mainly in Eastern Europe and Africa.John Lewis says this is the case with its scheme: the bought-back clothes will either be resold or recycled, but the trial is at too early a stage to give expected percentages in each case.What’s more, charities say donations are falling in the face of this High Street competition, and that criminals are also being drawn to the high prices — there’s reports of donations being stolen.Many firms have sprung up offering to collect clothes door-to-door for free. Shipping them off to be sold isn’t the end of it, though.Alan Wheeler, director of the Textile Recycling Association, says: ‘Just because a retailer collects garments doesn’t mean the problem is solved. Where do they go?‘Typically clothes go through a sorting programme and maybe 50 per cent will be sold for export.‘The rest will need to be recycled: sometimes they are cut for wiping cloths, depending on the material, or they are used to manufacture heat and sound insulation or filling materials such as mattress or duvet fillings.‘Some textiles are used to make “shoddy”, a wool-substitute yarn which can make blankets used in relief work. Recycled fibres can also be used to manufacture the interior linings in cars.‘Even if the used clothing is of good enough quality to be reused, eventually it will wear out and have to be either recycled or disposed of.‘Of course, it would be much better to be able to recycle these worn out items, so it would be good if new garments were designed with recycling in mind.’And in terms of the plastics used in clothes, controversially Wheeler says that if the public turned against polyster in favour of cotton, it would only be swapping one big environmental problem for another.          India Sturgis with the clothes mountain at the Oxfam Wastewise recycling centre in Batley, West Yorkshire Conventional cotton production can cause huge environmental problems. It typically takes 20,000 litres of water to produce just one kilogram of cotton.Polyester — a synthetic man-made polymer and mostly non-biodegradable plastic — is used in 60 per cent of our garments. The most common is polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, which is the same plastic used in soft drink and ketchup bottles.In many respects, polyester’s popularity is a no-brainer. It’s cheap, lightweight, shape-retaining, easy to blend with other materials and long-lasting. Manufacturing techniques have become so sophisticated that it can now be spun finer than a human hair.Forget the rough, thick polyester shirts of old — some modern polyesters rival even the most expensive natural fibres in quality.Polyester or otherwise, what’s the best way to recycle your clothes?The new app reGAIN might offer consumers something different to the High Street take-back schemes. The idea is simple — choose a minimum of ten items to package in a cardboard box and use the app to locate your closest drop-off point.You receive a discount code from the partner of your choice to go towards your next purchase. Above all, Wheeler prefers the good old-fashioned method of taking clothes to the local charity shop — where the money they raise will go to good causes.But what happens to your bag of old clothes once you drop it off?Most of us do not appreciate what a massive and sophisticated operation lies behind your humble, High Street charity shop.I paid a visit to Oxfam’s colossal clothing sorting centre, a 90,000 sq ft former bed-making factory — bigger than a football pitch — on the fringes of Batley in Yorkshire, to find out.Here any excess clothing from its charity shops is sorted — and the complexity of dealing with our fast fashion habit is clear.On the morning I visit, the deliveries are rolling in. Endless steel conveyor belts send streams of black bin bags to workers who sort their contents by hand.Out come Hobbs dresses, M&ampS cashmere cardigans, babies’ bibs, and old shirts and suits, which are flung into industrial wheelie bins for compressing and packing.The walls heave with hay-bale-sized bags of clothes stacked against them and there’s a smell of musty attic fibres in the air.Some 17 tonnes of clothing a day are sorted here. More than half is sent to Frip Ethique, the charity’s social enterprise project in Senegal providing work for 40 local men and women and stock for market traders. A large chunk of heavy-duty winter garments heads off to be commercially resold in Eastern Europe.Oxfam global ambassador Annie Lennox breaks her silence to...Halfords apologises for selling 'His and Hers' key rings...The must-have toys for Christmas... 200 days early!  2018...'I have been deeply concerned about our country': Starbucks'...Share this articleIf it can’t be worn again — the case in around a tenth of donations — it’s sold to recycling companies for industrial use as rags or mattress stuffing. Nothing — not one sock — gets sent to landfill.If items are too damp or dirty to process — around a minuscule 2 per cent of overall donations — they’re incinerated locally to produce energy for 400 Yorkshire homes.Despite this ingenuity, Lorraine Needham-Reid, the site’s manager of production, is still concerned about our wasteful attitude.‘I’m absolutely stunned by what people throw away,’ she says. ‘We see brand new items sent here, never worn, with tags still in. It is scary what people chuck out.’So what of the clothes we send to council recycling banks that are found on urban streets or in supermarket car parks?Sixty per cent is exported overseas for resale in second-hand clothing markets to countries such as Poland, Lithuania, Benin, Ghana and Togo.But this troubles Dr Andy Brooks, a lecturer in development geography at King’s College and author of Clothing Poverty, a book about fast fashion and the second-hand clothing sector.‘People think their old clothes are most likely to be sold in a local charity shop,’ he says. ‘However, there is a large international trade in used clothing that’s hidden from view.’‘Poor countries have had their markets flooded by second-hand garments.‘Factories in African countries including Ghana and Zambia have had to close down because they are uncompetitive.‘In the short term, cheap used clothing seems to be good for poor African consumers, but in the long term it harms their balance of trade and restricts industrial development.’So if recycling overseas is problematic when not overseen by an organisation such as Oxfam, and landfills equally so, could a beacon of hope be ‘fibre-to-fibre chemical recycling’ — essentially, making new garments out of old synthetic ones?Scientists have yet to find a workable method to magic synthetic clothing into new apparel — but the best attempt has so far come from outdoor clothing specialists Patagonia, who use PET clear plastic drinks bottles to make jackets, shorts and fleeces.But there are problems with taking that to the next stage, says Alan Wheeler.‘With polyester clothing you’ve got different dyes, you might have cotton threads within the item, it might have a nylon lining. Every item is different. Chemical recycling processes are looking at how to change all different polyester clothing into one homogenous product that can then be recycled easily.’ A move towards a circular clothing economy is something a few industry leaders are beginning to tentatively work towards.‘We need to slow down the amount we produce and encourage people to keep and use their clothes for longer,’ says Wheeler.‘The whole notion that celebrities and royals like the Duchess of Cambridge are radically “recycling” clothes when they’re spotted wearing the same item more than once is very frustrating. It should be considered normal practice,’ he adds.Wheeler points to the ‘elephant in the room’ when it comes to recycling and clothing retailers. ‘It is difficult for them to be sustainable because their survival is dependent on us buying more and more clothes,’ he says.‘I would argue that they need to encourage the public to buy less, pay more (that way they would pay their workers more, too) and design items that are made to last.’Currently consumer pressure for new garments means companies produce clothes faster to lower standards — which are then less able to withstand repeat wear.According to a recent report from WRAP, the average piece of clothing in the UK lasts for 3.3 years before being discarded.Other research puts the life of UK garments at 2.2 years.For a younger demographic, you can probably halve that. But the experts want us to do better than that.So it’s a case of step away from the shopping basket (literally or virtually), rewear what you already own, and recycle those you don’t — this way you save the planet as well as your pennies.

title: Londons Charing Cross station evacuated
story: Armed police attended Charing Cross this morning when it was reported that a man with an explosive device was on the tracks           Armed police rushed to Charing Cross station in the capital's centre this morning as a man claimed to have a bomb on the tracks     Police were called to Charing Cross station amid reports that a man on the tracks had a bombNetwork Rail said the mainline station, which caters for services arriving from the south east, was not evacuated, and arrivals and departures were not affected.   Passengers stuck on Northern Line trains faced huge delays to their journeys, as they were stuck on packed carriages waiting outside Charing Cross. Eyewitness Alan Buckingham tweeted: 'Loads of police including armed response at Charing Cross. title: Huge rise breeding cartoon face designer horses slammed vet
story: A horse called Jewel, who has been selectively bred, showing bulging eyes  A selectively bred horses teeth poking out of its mouth because there is no space in its mouth (left) and (right) an x-ray of a selectively bred horse's mouth with circles showing the gap where teeth have been unable to break through due to overcrowding (red) and teeth that have broken (green)Miss Fowler, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, sees at least one suffering animal every week for problems caused by 'cartoon' faces. She said: 'Humans have decided that some breeds look 'pretty' like this, but they haven't considering the resulting pony's ability to breathe or how their teeth are going to fit in their mouths.'These designer horses are sometimes referred to as 'Disney' horses because they look like cartoons with their pulled-in noses and popping-out eyes.'If it continues to get more extreme ponies may well face the problem of their eyes popping out as is common in brachycephalic dog breeds.'Over the last couple of years I'd say it's become particularly bad with the Arabs, miniatures and Welsh Section As.'          Miss Fowler (pictured with miniature horse Heathcliffe) sees at least one suffering animal every week for problems caused by 'cartoon' faces          Juno (pictured) is Jewel's mum who is not selectively bredHorror at Royal Ascot as racegoers travelling to Ladies Day...Racing cyclist 'smashes into a horse and then flips his...The horses bred to have cartoon faces: Vets' horror at...Share this articleMiss Fowler regularly sees ponies with health problems resulting from breeding for 'prettiness'.She says shrinking horses' noses causes a massive problem for their mouths as their teeth can't fit properly.The consequences can be dire to the horse's life , shrinking it considerably and tragically in most cases horse owners are not aware of the health issues faced by their pets.Despite owners sometimes splashing thousands of pounds to own one they often have to face the pain of putting a horse through risky surgery or putting them to sleep because the animals' quality of life is so poor.          The designer horses are sometimes referred to as 'Disney' horses, because they look like animals from the cartoons (pictured) with their pulled-in noses and popping-out eyes          Miss Fowler examining a horse's mouth at work in WiganIn October last year an Arabian show horse called El Rey Magnum was born in the US, and left experts horrified because of its concave face.The owners of the nine month old colt was said to resemble cartoon horses in Disney films Sleeping Beauty and Aladdin.Miss Fowler said: 'People seem to like these very dainty, pulled-in faces but that gives them breathing difficulties and dental problems. I'm seeing these deformities on a weekly basis.'One problem is there isn't enough space for their teeth because their mouths are smaller.          In October last year it emerged an Arabian show horse called El Rey Magnum (pictured) was born in the US, and left experts horrified because of its concave face          Example of extreme breeding, more usually seen in cats and dogs, can often be seen in the Arabian horse pedigree like Apalo, pictured, grandfather to El Rey Magnum'As a result the teeth grow everywhere and, in some cases, they'll make a whole space of their own behind the oral cavity because they can't fit in their mouths.'The x-ray from a horse I recently treated shows clearly that her teeth can't fit properly.'One is sitting behind her oral cavity, another has twisted 90 degrees because it wouldn't fit.'While human teeth are simple to extract, horse teeth can be anything from 8cm to 15cm long depending on the size of the horse. To extract a horse's tooth requires very big surgery.'One pony I recently treated is not expected to live very long at all now and she's only six. Selective breeding can certainly decrease life expectancy.'          Pedigree horses bred to have a concave face, pictured, has been described as ‘horrific’ by veterinary experts.Aside from the difficult situation of seeing their horse in pain, owners are often faced with bills reaching into the thousands due to the complexity of surgery.If surgery is needed it can be intense and 'massively risky' if the horse needs anaesthetic.Miss Fowler, who owns three horses herself, said: 'If a horse needs an operation the vet bills can be in the thousands. It is a much more serious procedure for horses than humans.'Ethically vets have to decide what is best for the horse because surgery is massively invasive.'Most owners decide they don't want to put their horses through it.'Horses have a one in 100 chance of death from general anaesthetic, compared with humans who have a one in 100,000 chance.'Any surgery is massively risky. It's very, very intense.'She claims it is often a horse's failure to show pain, as it is taught in the wild, that means owners are oblivious to the level of pain or suffering they are going through.As a result, it can already be too late by the time they visit the vet.'Usually the owners don't know their horses are in pain. Horses are prey animals - they don't show pain,' she said.'It's astonishing how severe the problems can get before the horses show any signs of pain or weight loss.'Pain is weakness in the wild and they would get eaten so often the problems are found when it is much too late to help the animal.'When found early, the owners are very surprised to find their animal is in pain.'The practice owner has now urged breeders to be more responsible, calling on them to consider functionality and what is best for the horse.Miss Fowler added: 'I think the focus needs to be on breeders as well as owners or buyers.'The breeders pushing for the extreme features that are causing the health issues are certainly irresponsible.'They breed for profit and create horses wanted for being pretty as opposed to functioning or healthy. That's the main source of the problem and it's definitely getting worse.'But while dogs can live on a soft diet without teeth if need be, horses need to eat grass for up to 20 hours a day.'People need to consider functionality and what is best for the horse. This is a massive problem in the horse world.'
