title: China news extinct ape Chinese tomb ancient gibbon junzi imperialis
story: The ancient gibbon was found buried next to an ancient Chinese royal, believed to have been her petThe new gibbon species, called Junzi imperialis, is believed to have been wiped out before the modern age as a result of human actions, leading to its extinction.This comes after researchers found the gibbon's partial skull buried beside an ancient Chinese royal, dating back 2,300 years.Dr Samuel Turvey, lead researcher of the Zoological Society of London, told Science magazine: All of the world's apes - chimpanzees, gorillas, orang-utans and gibbons - are threatened with extinction today due to human activities, but no ape species were thought to have become extinct as a result of hunting or habitat loss.However, the discovery of the recently extinct Junzi changes this, and highlights the vulnerability of gibbons in particular.                Baby gorilla gives hope for vanishing great ape                The utterly adorable moment a mother gorilla bonds with her tiny babyScientists unearthed the tomb in Shaanxi Province, central China, which also contained other animals' bones - including a lynx, leopards and a black bear.In ancient China, gibbons were deemed as noble animals and were often kept as luxury pets.It is believed the ape belonged to Lady Xia, the grandmother of China's first emperor, Qin Shihuang, who instructed his army to build the Great wall of China and the Terracotta Warriors.High-tech computer modelling software uncovered the new ape species - a genus gibbon which scientists estimate lived up to a few hundred years ago.ZSLThe extinct ape's skull was found buried in the tombDr Turvey said that any account of gibbons in China were only found in history books.He added: &ldquoIt is very, very far from any gibbon populations today.Chinese authorities banned Dr Turvey and his colleagues from extracting DNA from the bones, but they managed to conduct analyse the measurements of the gibbons and compare it&nbspwith existing ape species, discovering that its skull and jaw width belonged to an entirely new species.Researchers believe the gibbon species was wiped out as a result of intense human pressures on the environment, according to co-researcher Prof Helen Chatterjee of University College London.Ms Chatterjee said: Our historical data shows that these factors caused a southward shift of gibbons towards their present day distribution which is restricted to the very far south of China - and in the case of Junzi, its eventual extinction.It is believed the gibbon species' extinction was caused after the ancient Chinese expanded into the area's forest region, leading to its massive wipeout.Around 60 percent of all primate species around the world face the threat of extinction, including chimpanzees, gorillas and orangutans.

title: dominic grieve and his followers need to think about the consequences for britain if they keep blocking brexit
story: Dominic Grieve says he awakes in a cold sweat at the thought.But the former Attorney General is STILL prepared to collapse the government unless MPs get a final say on a no-deal Brexit.He likened leaving without an agreement to signing “a slavery clause”.Really? The country voted to remove the chains shackling us to Europe.Would he rather risk installing Jeremy Corbyn in No10 than leave the EU?Unless we’re prepared to walk away with no deal, we will be squeezed to a pulp by Brussels. Grieve knows this.The Remoaners are incapable of believing anything good can come from Brexit.Their apocalyptic paranoia downplays the uniqueness of our great country and the Blitz spirit that has guided us through far tougher times.The EU bloc is shrinking as the rest of the world’s economy booms.Who knows what our economy will look like in 10, 20, 30 years, or what advances will have been discovered?We will continue to weather storms, adapt and prosper.Meanwhile, the money we pay to Europe should be spent on services that benefit Brits.The £20billion NHS injection should be financed by the “Brexit dividend” - or savings.It shouldn’t come from the pockets of hard-working Sun readers already clobbered by the taxman.Grieve’s followers should think very carefully about unleashing chaos.The potential consequences are dire.HOME Secretary Sajid Javid was right to return medicinal cannabis oil to a boy suffering from epileptic seizures.The medication is legal in 13 European countries and 30 US states.Research suggests it can benefit cancer, HIV and MS sufferers. title: frankies new world order brings me out in noyles
story: Probably not.But the answer’s there for you anyway, if you want to see, at 10pm, BBC2, Friday.It’s called Frankie Boyle’s New World Order and is officially classed, by listings, as a “comedy”, even though it’s nothing of the sort.That’s just a Get Out Of Jail card for BBC2, because New World Order is very obviously a political discussion show featuring a host and four guests who represent every possible shade of opinion, from the hard left to the extreme left.Typically, these will be Sara Pascoe, Katherine Ryan,  statistics expert Mona Chalabi, who’s as funny as her job suggests, and a token male in Miles Jupp or David Baddiel, whose purpose is to sit there, furiously agreeing with everything the women say.Starting point here will be a “light-hearted” subject that plays to the collective bias.One week, for instance, it was “Donald Trump will be the first crowd-funded assassination”.A move the panel eventually seemed to rule out, not on the grounds it’s morally wrong, but that it would: “Make him a martyr.”On the eve of Harry and Meghan’s wedding it was “We have 12 hours to abolish the monarchy”, which ended with a huge round of applause for Frankie’s suggestion of “executing them”.If you’re waiting for me here to tell you one person demurred or looked a bit ashamed, you haven’t been watching BBC comedy recently.There is no shame or opposition these days, least of all from the host, who’s made one of the more remarkable transformations of recent times.Just eight years ago, Frankie was telling jokes about disabled children, now here he is, via a column in , preaching about “the inhumanity of the Tories” and parading his apparent concerns for the children of Palestine.Remarkable, but I guess that’s what happens if the BBC decide you’re “One of us”.You get your own show and a stand-up slot at the beginning of each episode, where Frankie settles scores in his usual gear-crunching style.Targets may be Brexit, the Tories, America and Israel one week. Israel, America, the Tories and Brexit the next.Corbyn’s off limits, obviously, as Frankie thinks he’s “a real person”, but there’s a regular cast of soft targets, including Donald Trump, Richard Branson (“a c***”), Boris, Michael Gove, Ruth Davidson (“a bastard”) and usually a joke about Prince Philip dying, which I think we can put down to the host’s very obvious and well-deserved self-loathing.Prince Philip, after all, was mentioned in dispatches fighting real Nazis in World War Two, instead of just ranting about them to a couple of hundred students at the Edinburgh Fringe.At the age of 97, The Duke is also still a thousand times more unpredictable, off-message, edgy and funny than any of the people on NWO and, unlike Frankie, who has 11 scriptwriters, also comes up with his own material.The hatred and abuse of Israel is slightly harder to explain, though. Frankie claims it’s because “They break international law”, but then so do a lot of countries, including Russia, which even shoots down passenger aircraft.A stroke of luck then, you might think, that the BBC’s just screened Frankie’s two-part, pre-World Cup travelogue, Frankie Goes To Russia, where, unfortunately, he didn’t have time to raise the issue of the aircraft, but he did go on Moscow radio to denounce the British Empire (topical or what!).If you were expecting anything else, of course, you give Frankie Boyle more credit than his apparent cowardice and hypocrisy deserves.If you were also expecting laughter, then I applaud your optimism, but you’ll no more get it on NWO than on Have I Got News For You, or The Mash Report, or any of those other shows that have decided the right-on part of the world is untouchable and their own left-wing agenda is far more important than being funny.The BBC’s continuing claims of impartiality, on the other hand? Well, forgive me if I let out the hollowest laugh of my life, but they are really, darkly funny.Ha . . .— GIVEN the BBC’s endless, self-serving and grovelling tributes to the NHS are still very much ongoing, I feel it would be wrong, at this point, if I didn’t join in the birthday celebrations.For though it has its faults and is often criticised, it’s been there for us, healing the lame, curing the sick, becoming the envy of the world, a shining beacon to the entire universe, which makes me fall to my knees and give thanks for seven decades’ service at the mere mention of its sacred initials.Happy 71st, Bupa.All those liars who say they want fat, unattractive people on Love Island. The disturbing Trouble With Women revelation that Anne Robinson keeps a scrapbook of her old newspaper columns, when so many hamsters still go without decent bedding every night.And The X Factor giving a job not just to Robbie Williams, who’s won 18 Brit awards and five Ivor Novello awards, but also his wife, Ayda Field, who handed Emmerdale the NTA’s 2017 Best Soap award. There on merit . . .IF you have ever wondered why some people are so dementedly pleased to see the World Cup arrive, try watching daytime TV just before the ball-kicking tournament starts.I did last Wednesday and quickly fell down a QVC rabbit hole, where I discovered Amanda Holden has a neat line in selling stuff nobody actually needs but everyone seems to want.Suitcases that aren’t really suitcases, string chairs designed to look like a cat’s sphincter, rugs that would make a Moroccan fez salesman blush, machine-woven toilet roll baskets, lamp-shades so taut and expressionless they could sit on the Britain’s Got Talent panel, if you just pre-programmed them with a dirty laugh.Amanda’s exclusive landfill range has the lot. Piece de resistance, though, has to be her “glass infinity spheres”, which defy any sort of purpose or description, but she had a crack anyway.“They’re, uhm, a bit like those things in the ’80s and ’90s you put fingers and hands on.”Lava lamps? Tamagotchis? Les Dennis? Sadly, we may never know.The afternoon’s real curve ball, though, was introduced by QVC’s endlessly enthusiastic host Pipa Gordon, vis-a-vis lightbulbs: “Amanda, bayonet or screw?”Get back to you, Pipa. I’m just emailing a format idea to ITVBe.Sophie and Sadie both switching their lights off the moment 5ive’s Ritchie Neville burst into song on a celebrity version of Take Me Out.The One Show’s Alex Jones telling David Walliams: “You’re handsome . . . in a different way.”And a dreadful opening to the World Cup being elevated by the brilliant Spain versus Ronaldo game, ITV’s superior selection of pundits and Wrighty, very solemnly assuring us: “I think Suarez has got a big one in him.”—TUESDAY, Good Morning Britain calls in the big diplomatic hitter to comment on the US/North Korea peace deal.Singer Michael Ball: “I would feel better if it wasn’t those two having the conversation.“But there is nothing better than people talking, ’cos . . . ”’Cos love, love changes everything. Hands and faces, earth and sky.AFTER a relatively slow start, Love Island is now in the groove and I am totally immersed. To such an extent that I developed a really strong loathing for a couple of the contestants last week.Namely, Eyal, who’s as ruthless and possessive as the next smirking little berk who claims he’s “spiritual”, and Hayley, a venomous little madam whose description of herself – “I’m cute, funny, feisty, dozy” – is a million miles away from anyone else’s, unless the Theatre Royal St Helens is seriously short of dwarves next Christmas.Fortunately, she’s gone now and there are quite a few of the Islanders that I do actually like.Stationery-obsessed Jack, who has Dancing On Ice 2019 written all over him, top secret Josh, who can’t say too much about his job (taps nose) and Laura, who, like every Scottish woman ever born, is incapable of disguising her feelings, good or bad, and has a biological clock that’s ticking like a Countdown Conundrum.It’s the production that still sets Love Island apart, though, and the fact it’s the only reality show which would drop Beethoven’s Pastoral Symphony into the mix or have the wit to pay off the Alex/Eyal showdown with this news: “Megan had to choose between a man who saves lives with his bare hands and a boy who can walk up and down in a straight line while pouting.“There was only ever going to be one winner.”Brilliant television.Steve Wilson: “Portugal’s big man in the sky is on the pitch.”Alex Scott: “Croatia looked lustlackre.”Glenn Hoddle: “The Ref saw it so he must have been watching.”THIS week’s winner is Gemma Collins and Tiffany from Bride Of Chucky. Sent in by Connor David, via email.Picture research: Alfie Snelling.GOOD Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “I love salad.”Good Morning Britain, Susanna Reid: “I’m totally neutral when it comes to politics.” (Dyed-in-the-wool BBC left-of-centre about everything).And Love Island, Alex on Megan revealing she’s a stripper: “I think that showed such character and strength. I really respect her for that.”(Would like to see her with her kit off.)Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit vote trevor kavanagh
story: She won a crucial vote on Brexit, but only after giving embittered anti-Brexit Speaker John Bercow a final say on Parliament’s right to veto the whole deal.This may be a procedural technicality, but it is still madness.She is now careering from one self-inflicted crisis to the next, assailed by the Remainers she truly supports but held on two feet by Brexiters who cannot allow her to fall . . . yet.This zombie Government is kept on life support not by fellow Remainers but by true Brexit believers who want her to carry the can.This cannot last. There must be a new Tory leader and a new Prime Minister. Only because these are not necessarily the same thing has she survived this long.Both Inners and Outers are mortal enemies but neither wants to risk inflicting a Marxist Labour victory on this country.Mrs May is entirely to blame. She began the Brexit negotiation with several trump cards.The greatest was the threat to walk away.Brussels was genuinely terrified we would set up a competitive low-tax rival which would expose its own economic incompetence.Instead, the PM immediately handed Brussels all her aces — plus a sack-load of taxpayers’ cash.It’s impossible to see how Mrs May can extricate Britain from the calamity she is inflicting.The result is a hideous mess which risks miring the UK in years of rancour and recrimination, not just with Europe but within the Conservative Party, the Labour Party and, above all, the voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rikki neave cps insufficient evidence
story: The young boys body was found in a wooded area of Peterborough over two decades ago - he had been strangled.A 36-year-old man from Peterborough was arrested in April 2016 on suspicion of murder but was later released with no further action.And today Paul Scothern of the CPS, said: “Once the police have carried out an investigation, a file of evidence may be submitted to the CPS.“This file is then reviewed in line with the Code for Crown Prosecutors, which outlines the standards that prosecutors must follow when they make decisions about whether charges can be brought.In order to begin a prosecution, we have to be satisfied there is sufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction and that it is in the public interest to prosecute.“We considered a range of evidence obtained by police from the time of Rikki’s disappearance to the recent reinvestigation.“We have decided that the evidence is insufficient for a realistic prospect of conviction and therefore for charge.“The deliberate killing of a child is shocking and tragic, but we cannot bring charges if there is not enough evidence to take to court.Rikki’s family have been informed of our decision and given a full explanation. We have also offered to meet with them.A team of more than 25 officers from the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit have spent the past three years meticulously investigating Rikki’s murder.Assistant Chief Constable Paul Fullwood, who leads the three force Joint Protective Services, said: “It is disappointing that following our three year investigation we have not been able to identify the person or persons responsible for Rikki’s murder.“However, although at this stage we have no further active lines of enquiry we remain committed to finding his killer.  It is frustrating that despite three years of detailed investigations we are not able to tell Rikki’s family what happened on the day of his murder but we will not give up hope to do so one day.“Whether it be new evidence or advances in forensic science, we will utilise every opportunity to investigate this murder and bring an offender to justice.“We strongly believe someone out there knows the truth and remain hopeful that one day will come to light.The young boys mum, Ruth, was tried and acquitted of his murder in 1996 - she received a seven year jail sentence after pleading guilty to child neglect offences.The case was re-opened as a cold case in June 2015 by officers of the Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit.

title: theresa may britain defence power
story: It emerged that the PM has clashed with her Defence Secretary by questioning the need for the UK to continue to be a ‘Tier One’ power.The term means having a full spectrum of capabilities, from nuclear weapons and aircraft carriers to submarines and special forces.Pressed by The Sun to reassure worried generals, the PM refused to repeat the all-important Tier One term.Instead, she would only say: “The reports that you have read are not correct.“We will continue to be a leading defence nation.“The United Kingdom is a leading member of the NATO alliance.“We are the second biggest defence budget in NATO. We are the biggest defence budget in Europe.”Mrs May also insisted Britain will “continue to spend 2% of our GDP on defence” – the standing NATO cash target - while MPs have implored here to hike the MoD’s money to 3%.The Premier’s evasion rang immediate alarm bells among furious Tory MPs and only intensified fears of a bitter new round of defence cuts.Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson is locked in a struggle with Chancellor Philip Hammond for more money to fill a £20bn blackhole in the defence budget.Former Army-turned-Tory MP Johnny Mercer said: “If the PM thinks that we are no longer going to be a Tier One military nation, then she will have a serious disagreement with me and a number of other Conservative backbenchers.“It is unthinkable that she would want Britain’s role in the world to diminish.“I will be pressing the PM for clarification of what this would mean for an already heavily pressurised defence budget.”The Sun can also reveal that Downing Street has demanded military chiefs bury a report on the spiralling security threats to Britain in a bid to keep a lid on calls for more defence cash.Mrs May and Mr Hammond have ordered Mr Williamson not to publish findings of an MoD funding review that highlight the new danger Russia poses until at least December.That is a month after fresh money is handed out to other departments such as health in the Budget in November.Mr Stoltenberg said: “Some question the bond between Europe and the US.But we’ve had differences before. The lesson of history is we overcome those differences.”The Defence Secretary had pledged to unveil the work in time for NATO’s annual summit next month.A senior defence source said: “No10 and No11 just want this to all go away, because they’ve spent any money we could have had on the NHS.Mrs May spoke as she met NATO’s Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg in No10 for talks to halt Donald Trump from walking out on the transatlantic alliance.Fears are also mounting that the US President will use its annual get-together to announce a devastating American withdrawal of military support until the other 28 members start stumping up more cash for their defence budgets.Pleading for military spending to increase across Europe, Mr Stoltenberg said: ““What makes NATO unique is the bond between Europe and America. title: defy brussels laws sun says post brexit immigration policy
story: It may comply with Brussels’ rules. So what? Why stick by those after we leave? As an independent nation we should kick out serious criminals we are not bound to keep.Why too are we unilaterally offering all EU nationals arriving by 2021 the “lifetime right” to bring their entire family?What is Brussels offering in return?The Sun is not against immigration. We want only to control the numbers while picking the most skilled migrants to boost our economy. But yet again our Government is rolling over and volunteering new concessions to the EU.Its faith that Brussels will look kindly on our generosity is staggeringly naive.Are the other 27 EU countries now busily reassuring our expats or extending open invitations to Brits? Are they hell.Just as depressingly, the Home Office ­hasn’t a clue how many EU citizens will take us up on our offer. Could be three million, they say. Or nearer four.What’s another million, eh?Their indifference is jaw-dropping.The nation has endured years of belt-tightening and is taxed to the hilt.There is clearly room to borrow a little more and find savings elsewhere. The first option being the £14billion foreign aid budget which even Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt admits is indefensible.The Tories should cut it by two-thirds and give the lot to health. But it would need a law change they won’t entertain.So they must find imaginative ways to use aid to bail out other departments.The Tories must not impose new taxes. Especially while they still dole out our money to corrupt regimes, vanity projects and charities staffed by sex predators.The public won’t wear it.DONALD Trump aims to strong-arm Nato members into paying more into the pot — with the same brinkmanship he used on North Korea. title: british airways hero pilot las vegas airport burst flames
story: It said Captain Chris Henkey did not follow standard procedures when the Boeing 777 burst into flames after the left engine failed during take off in September 2015.Passengers could not escape through two exits because emergency slides were blown out of position by an engine which Henkey should have shut down, US investigators found.A further four exits could not be used due to the blaze, meaning everyone on board had to leave through just two doors before smoke and fire engulfed the fuselage.The investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) found the blaze was caused by a fatigue crack in part of the engine, a General Electric model, leading to a fuel leak.Two seconds after hearing a bang, Henkey from Reading, Berkshire, aborted the take off, bringing the jet to a stop on the runway just 13 seconds later.He ordered passengers to evacuate from the right side of the plane but the unaffected right engine continued to run for 43 seconds after his command, preventing two slides from being used.The NTSB found that Mr Henkey did not use his quick reference handbook to read the evacuation checklist, attempting to perform the tasks from memory.It added: He missed the second step, which was to ensure that both engines were shut down.Because the captain did not follow standard procedures, his call for the evacuation checklist and the shutdown of the right engine were delayed.The last person left the aircraft two minutes and 32 seconds after the captains initial command to evacuate.A BA spokesman said: We fully supported the NTSB investigation, which did not identify any safety recommendations for British Airways.The safety of our customers and crew is always our very first priority.Our crew responded quickly and decisively bringing the aircraft to a swift halt, assessing the situation and safely evacuating the aircraft.During the evacuation, one passenger was walked over after stumbling onto the aisle, while another was pushed down a slide after stopping at the top to remove her shoes, the NTSB reported. A flight attendant was seriously injured when she fell after reaching the bottom of a slide, breaking her forearm and suffering a compression fracture in her back.The slide was wet and slippery after being sprayed with an extinguishing agent by the fire service and 19 passengers were hurt in the evacuation.Many passengers took their carry-on baggage off the plane.The NTSB warned that this could potentially delay an evacuation, although it was not a factor in the Las Vegas incident.Mr Henkey was praised in the immediate aftermath of the fire for how quickly he brought the jet to a halt.His quick response was described as textbook by aviation experts, while he was reportedly applauded by passengers when he met them in the Las Vegas airport terminal building.The NTSB found that he had made a timely decision to reject the takeoff and performed the manoeuvre in accordance with company training and procedures.It was due to be his penultimate flight before retirement after 42 years of flying, but he admitted he was unlikely to make his final flight following the fire.

title: eu citizens are our friends family and colleagues and are welcome post brexit minister promises
story: Revealing the Home Offices plan to register EU nationals after we leave the EU, Caroline Nokes insisted yesterday that the new system would be easy and straightforward for anyone to use.She told MPs in the House of Commons that up to four million EU citizens would be welcome to stay after Brexit, and would be able to bring over their spouse, family or even a girlfriend or boyfriend if they had been together more than two years.Ms Nokes said: EU citizens make a huge contribution to our economy and our way of life, they are our friends, family and colleagues and we want them to stay.Ministers insisted that they are working hard on delivering the system on mobile devices, so citizens can simply scan and upload documents to their phone and snap a selfie to prove who they are. It is hoped it will be ready in just a few months, so they can have years to prepare everyone for our EU exit.They will have to pay £65 in order to register and stay here - which is cheaper than the price of a British passport.He told a Lords committee today that minister want to make it as simple as possible and might not involve any paperwork having to be sent in to them.Mr Javid said. You have an app, you can put your passport next to your phone, and it will download your information.Then you can take a selfie - Im sure youve done that many times - you download it too, and match the information downloaded with the chip and confirm it electronically.Other details like National Insurance numbers would be taken through the app and cross referenced with existing information.But he also had to admit that there was an issue at the moment with whether it would work on iPhones, because of problems with Apples technology.However, ministers are working on the issue with Apple, and hope to get it resolved in time for the apps launch in the autumn.Mr Javid said he wanted trials to start in July with a full roll out following a few months later.And for those less tech savvy EU citizens, Mr Javid said they would be setting up shop in libraries and local council buildings to help register people in person too.Theresa May has already agreed that the millions of EU nationals living in the UK can remain for life – if they apply for settled status.Ex-Home Secretary Amber Rudd in April said the residency application system would be “as easy” as setting up an online account at luxury brand LK Bennett.Yesterday Sajid Javid said he would be looking for reasons “to grant, not refuse” a right to remain.The scheme offers more “generous” rights than first planned- and better terms to those awarded to British nationals with foreign partners.Home Secretary Sajid Javid said answers will be checked and decisions given “very quickly”. There would have to be “a very good reason” for refusal.But critics accused ministers of giving in too much to the EU.Alp Mehmet, of the Migration Watch think tank said: “The government seem to have conceded almost every point demanded by the EU.“Meanwhile there is very little evidence that EU member states have done anything to speak of for British residents in their countries.”A row over criminal checks threatened to block the entire withdrawal agreement between the UK and EU last year. The Home Office yesterday insisted background checks would only be carried out where they had concerns.Tory backbencher Philip Davies called for more clarity from the Home Office. He said: “It seems to me the presumption is the wrong way round. My view is that if anyone commits a crime they should be booted out.“Being in this country is a privilege.”

title: mystery victorian ghost watching boy bike solved
story: Mum Louise Lenton, 41, noticed the figure as she looked back over the clip recorded on a visit to Oldway Mansion in Paignton, Devon - but it turns out it was a security guard not a ghost.It shows her five-year-old son circling the car park on his cycle.In a window on the first floor a figure can be seen which Louise thought might have been the ghost of a Victorian woman.Louise, from Paignton, Devon, said: It looks like a lady with hair in a bun, with white cuffs around her hands.Torbay Council told her that security guards would have been inside the building at the time the footage was recorded.But Louise insisted: Its certainly not a security guard from what I can tell. The outfit the woman is wearing appears to have white cuffs and it looks Victorian.I would love to know who or what it was.Now though, a security guard has come forward to say the he was indeed the mystery figure.Alex Warren, who has worked at Oldway Mansion for four years, explained: I wear my black cardigan inside and my security coat for outside patrols.That day I was just admiring the young lad, learning to ride his bike.Hope this clears up the misunderstanding.There are, to my knowledge, no ghosts at Oldway, and I have worked days and nights here for over four years.Speaking at the time Louise said: My partner and I had split off, with him going to walk the dogs on the fields and I took our little boy to the car park to practise riding his bike.The car park is flat and perfect to do it. I was just filming him and that was it.It wasnt until I was home and in bed watching the film back when I noticed it.I was like, Oh my gosh and my partner could not explain it. Neither of us know what this is.When I was filming I didnt see it at all. I was too busy filming. I screenshotted it and zoomed in straight away.The Grade II-listed mansion was constructed at vast expense in 1871 by Isaac Singer - the founder of the Singer sewing machine company.Set in 17 acres of Devon countryside, it was later rebuilt by his son Paris in the style of the Palace of Versailles.The family lived there until the end of World War I, when it became a hospital.During World War II it was home to RAF cadets undergoing air crew training before being sold to Torbay Borough Council.It was then used as offices and a venue for civil marriage ceremonies until the council moved out five years ago.It has been empty ever since.In 2004 it doubled as Buckingham Palace for the Christian Slater film Churchill: The Hollywood Years.

title: roma travellers claim hull like holiday
story: The Roma gypsies arrived on Wednesday from Appleby in Cumbria and are made up of five families with over a dozen children in six caravans.They have set up their camp on grassland close to residential properties and have even strung their washing up between trees.One member of the group - Colleen Price, 30, said: “We like Hull. It’s a lovely place, the people are civilised and we have had no trouble from them or from the police.“We’re five families and we all travel together. Our culture is that we can’t sit still and stay in the same place.This is what we are used to doing. We travel all summer and go to gypsy fairs. It’s good. I like it.”“We’ve got no rubbish and everything is bagged up. This is like a holiday for us.Some people can afford to go abroad but we can’t. We are poor – we are not millionaires so this is our holiday.“We are here, the horses are grazing and tethered down, the children are well fed and I just think it is lovely.”She says their reception has been mostly positive but there has been an isolated case of abuse.Coleen explained: “A boy on a motorbike came and he was very abusive.He swore like no tomorrow and said a lot of dirty language. Some people are just like that.“But on the whole everything is good.We have had people come up to us and talk to us and at the end of the day if you are civilised to us, we will be civilised towards you.”Another traveller - Mary Smith, 17, said the group will not be hurried into leaving before they are ready.She stated: “This is our way and how we live our lives. We have not had any permission to stay here but no one has come to us yet.“The council might come to us today and if they do they will give us a date to get off.If we don’t they will take us to court but we will go before anything happens.“We keep it quite short and go between places and we think we will be alright here until next Saturday.”A spokesperson for Hull City Council said We are aware that travellers have set up an unauthorised encampment and legal proceedings are under way.”

title: sas who dares wins dan cross engaged to alex wells
story: Dan Cross, a dad-of-two, listened helplessly as wife Nicola was killed in front of their kids in September 2015.Now the 40-year-old has heartwarmingly revealed he will wed Alex Wells, 27, a mental health physician and graduate of Bournemouth University.He told BBC Three Counties Radio: Im engaged to Alex. Shes a remarkable woman. Were moving forward and hopefully going to get married next year. The children are really happy.The dad-of-two heard everything as wife Nicola was tragically stabbed to death by a schizophrenic home invader as she protected their kids Stanley, six, and Isabella, three.Mr Cross, an IT specialist, was working away from home at the time and 200 miles away in Hull when, during a phone call with Nicola, he heard her desperate fight for life.He appeared on the latest series of Channel 4s SAS: Who Dares Wins, in which ex-Special Forces soldiers put recruits through a gruelling recreation of the SAS selection process.The 40-year-old had ex-Special Forces hardmen Jason Fox and Ant Middleton in tearful silence as he revealed the harrowing details of that night.Marcin Porczynski, then 27 and a schizophrenic, broke into the familys home late at night intending to kidnap their two young children while Mr Cross was working in Hull.Reliving the night of his wifes death, he said today: Nikki just called me late in the evening and said she was worried about somebody outside the house and the police had been earlier.The children were in bed at the time, Stanley was six and Isabella was three. So we were discussing options on the phone, what to do. But before she could do anything, the guy broke in through the back doors and killed her.I heard it all down the phone. Its complete shock, you dont know whats going on. I felt utterly heartless. I was on the phone to the police on the other line, trying to relay information.I didnt know what had happened to the children till I heard them crying on the phone and then I thought they were OK.Mr Cross said after the killing he and his two kids moved in with his parents but he returned to his former home occasionally so he could let out his emotions in private.He underwent trauma counselling afterwards and said he experienced flash backs within the first month after Nicola died.I felt like I couldnt breathe, I was back in that moment and then I realised if Im going to be a good dad to the kids and make sure theyre confident, happy adults then I need to get help, he said.In January this year Mr Cross revealed he was doing really well and had found love again with 27-year-old Alex.Discussing his new relationship he said: She came in and sort of let everything wash over her. Its a brave decision to get involved with a family thats had something like that happen to them.Shes been perfect with the children. [In her job] she specialises in under fives but she can do things with the kids, techniques and things, that I dont know anything about.Its been amazing, quite freaky really, to have someone come in whos so perfect.Porczynski pleaded guilty at St Albans Crown Court in December 2016 to Nikkis manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility and was ordered to be detained in a secure psychiatric unit for an indefinite period.The court heard he was suffering from paranoid schizophrenia at the time of the attack and had been hearing voices for up to two years before the killing.Got a story? email digishowbiz@the-sun or call us direct on 02077824220.We pay for videos too. title: what frankie dettori told meghan markle royal ascot 2018
story: Prince Harry wagged his finger at the diminutive Italian as the athlete joked his kids would be more excited about his meeting Meghan Markle than him winning the race.The 47-year-old had just won the St Jamess Palace Stakes on horse Without Parole on Tuesday, putting the 33-year-old royal on his guard when he pecked Meghan on the hand.The 5ft 4in sportsman today revealed what sparked Prince Harrys sudden reaction, telling Ladbrokes: I told her my kids will be more excited about me meeting you than me winning the race, but then Harry started wagging his finger!Despite Frankies nonchalance, he actually didnt break protocol.According to royal.uk there are no obligatory codes of behaviour when meeting The Queen or a member of the Royal Family.But there was a sting for the jockey, who was suspended and fined £4,300 for using his whip above the permitted level from approaching two furlongs out during his winning race.The Duke and Duchess had caused a sensation when they arrived at the event earlier this week.The newlyweds arrived in a horse-drawn carriage alongside the Count and Countess of Wessex.They were followed swiftly by the Queen, wearing a bright yellow jacket and matching hat, who was accompanied by her daughter, Princess Anne.Meghan, wearing a elegant white dress and Harry in top and tails, waved to excited crowds who had packed out the race course in Berkshire.Their appearance at the eagerly anticipated race event came hours after Kensington Palace announced that their first official foreign trip as a couple would be to Dublin, in July. Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall were also spotted arriving at Royal Ascot with Princesses Eugenie and Beatrice travelling in another carriage, after.Missing from the royal party was Zara Phillips and Mike Tindall, who announced the birth of their second child earlier that day.Armed cops had been seen patrolling the race tracks bars and enclosures.Recent race days have been marred by unsavoury booze-fuelled antics, with video footage emerging of a mass brawl between men at Ascot in May.The incident took place a week after another man was filmed being kicked in the head during a fight at Goodwood races in Sussex.Goodwood chiefs are so sick of the bad behaviour that they have limited punters to buying fours drinks one time.However, it is not thought that Ascot has taken similar measures. Meghan has appeared comfortable in filling her new role as a royal, having taken on her first event without Prince Harry.The American visited Cheshire with The Queen earlier this month, appearing to be extremely close with the 92-year-old monarch.The pair even shared a joke as they took their seats for a childrens music medley performance.

title: army vet admits chewing off his mums head after cops find her decapitated remains in the back garden
story: Terrelle Johnson, 29, is said to have admitted killing mother Sherry after her decapitated body was found in their back garden in Stone County, Mississippi.Capt. Ray Boggs of the Stone County Sheriff’s Department recounted what was said at a preliminary hearing on Wednesday .According to the Sun Herald, he said: “(Johnson) told me that he beat her up real bad.“He said it got out of hand.”Using a butter knife, Johnson allegedly sliced his mother’s throat and then used his teeth and bare hands to remove her head, claimed Boggs.Johnson also claimed he choked her unconscious first during a fight over credit cards.When cops arrived at the Johnson home June 6 — to conduct a welfare check on Sherry at the request of her two brothers and sister, who hadn’t heard from the 51-year-old since June 3 — they found her mutilated body in the garden.Her head had been tossed over a fence.Johnson — an Army vet who was expelled by the Department of Veterans Affairs after a prior arrest — allegedly confessed to everything, though it’s unclear when his mother’s murder took place.A grand jury must now decide whether he should be formally charged.Johnson’s lawyer, Jim Davis, told reporters that he is currently weighing the possibility of an insanity defence.He said: “(Johnson) does have a substantial history and you all heard details of the case.“That’s not a normal homicide … (but) we’ve got to wait until we get the records and probably have him properly evaluated.“Then, we’ll kind of know where we’re headed.”

story: It begins with Corden ringing Sir Paul and asking for his "help", adding that he "needs somebody, not just anybody".Within seconds of the former Beatle arriving, the pair are driving through the streets of Liverpool singing Drive My Car.Penny Lane is also on the itinerary, where Sir Paul autographs a street sign and they spot the barber shop in the song, nipping in for a chat. title: public places brought together being
story: NewsopinionPublic places that brought us together are being sold off in the name of austerityThe Great British Sell Off, produced by charity Locality – who dug out figures via FOI requests – says 20,651 public assets were sold off in the last five years alone&nbspShareByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist23:23, 21 JUN 2018NewsopinionHastings pier in Sussex has been sold for the knockdown fairground stall price of £50,000&nbspShareGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUntil a few months ago, the iconic Victorian pier at Hastings belonged to the town’s people. Last Friday, it emerged the 1872 landmark had been sold to tycoon Sheikh Abid Gulzar for the knockdown fairground stall price of &pound50,000. This is despite the fact that as recently as 2012, the pier was saved for the community by amazing local campaigners and a &pound12million lottery grant. Another local group, Friends of Hastings Pier, had a new not-for-profit plan waiting in the wings, and were on the verge of reaching &pound50,000 with a crowdfunder. But the administrators preferred Mr Gulzar – who has banned dog walkers, cyclists, fishing and picnics at nearby Eastbourne Pier, and threatened to introduce an entrance fee.  And the cash-strapped, austerity-hit council were powerless to help. This is heartbreaking for Hastings, but the pier is just one of an estimated 4,000 public spaces being sold off every year in every austerity-squeezed town in the country, according to a new report. The Great British Sell Off, produced by charity Locality – who dug out figures via FOI requests – says 20,651 public assets were sold off in the last five years alone. Locality chief Tony Armstrong points out that “4,000 buildings is more than four times the number of Starbucks in the UK”. Many are being lost to private developers for the highest price and will never be used by the community again. Some, like Hornsey Town Hall in London, are being made into flats while others, like the former Grade II listed Ealing Town Hall in West London and the landmark Liverpool Municipal Buildings, will become luxury hotels. In West Yorkshire, residents are trying to save the former Dewsbury Museum, closed by the council in 2016 after 120 years.  For the last 18 months, I’ve been retracing George Orwell’s Road to Wigan Pier through the industrial North and Midlands – and this great sell-off of our public spaces has been evident in every town in the country. Wigan Pier was basically a music hall joke about a coal jetty in landlocked Wigan, but across the country we’ve found evidence of the local authority fire sale. Privatised piers and boarded-up or flogged-off libraries, swimming pools, working men’s clubs, lidos, town halls, museums, youth centres have all been sold to the highest bidder. As councils have been squeezed by the Government and forced to choose between adult social care or keeping a museum open, they’ve felt forced to choose human care. But the result is all the places where we used to come together from our different walks of life have been shuttered up and closed off. The Government recently recognised we have a crisis of loneliness and yet what’s lonelier than having nowhere to go? We have a crisis of social cohesion, but nowhere we might bump into each other. Young people are being drawn into gangs by hanging out on street corners, but what about the places they used to go to? We have a crisis of working class people not going to into arts or sport, and yet the free places in which they used to access those things are derelict. Even estate pubs and local football clubs are being forced to close.

title: tory brexit playing russian roulette
story: NewsopinionThis Tory Brexit is playing Russian roulette with British jobsThe Airbus warning shows the Conservatives are putting tens of thousand of jobs at risk with their "dangerous" Brexit, writes Len McCluskey&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLen McCluskey16:41, 22 JUN 2018NewsopinionAirbus has warned it could move out of the UK because of Brexit (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWell now we know what we always feared.  A Tory Brexit is dangerously bad for British jobs.       One of our foremost manufacturers, Airbus, has warned that without frictionless access to our European Union markets, it cannot see a future in the UK.       From the home of Concorde in Bristol, to Portsmouth and Newport, to Stevenage and Scotland, Airbus sustains 100,000 manufacturing and related jobs.      While the impact of any Airbus exit will fall heaviest on 6000 Broughton workers in North Wales, thousands more in the supply chain hang in the balance. There is not a part of the country that won’t suffer.         Yet the fate of these workers now lie in the hands of a squabbling Tory party.       It has been two years since the Brexit vote - but we are no further forward today in understanding where this government is taking us in March 2019 than we were in June 2016.       At this rate, hemmed in by the Tories’ destructive red lines, all the signs are that we will crash out without a deal.       So when the government breezily says that it is confident that it will get a deal that will meet the need of Airbus and manufacturers like them, who are they trying to kid?      People are not fools.  Yes, there was a vote to leave the EU – and that must be respected - but it was not a vote to lose our jobs.      The chill wind of a Tory Brexit is now blowing through our communities.

title: tory minister demands comedian ricky
story: NewsTory minister demands comedian Ricky Gervais apologises for branding ME sufferers 'lazy' in offensive jokeThe Office funnyman was accused of stigmatising the disease&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJohn SiddleNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:23, 22 JUN 2018Updated15:54, 22 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Government minister has demanded Ricky Gervais publicly apologise for a joke branding ME sufferers lazy. The Office funnyman was called out in a parliamentary debate and accused of stigmatising the disease. MP Steve Brine criticised Gervais for an old gag where he allegedly described ME as “the one where...‘I don’t feel like going to work today’. The Minister for Primary Care said: We recognise that people with ME have encountered significant stigma, in part due to the unfavourable media representations of the condition that not only go back to the 1980s but have continued in recent times Mr Brine used the the offensive joke as an example, telling MPs : I have to say that Ricky Gervais is a very talented comic but given that he’s quite active on Twitter, maybe he could just be asked to retract that and apologise to the ME community for that comment today on Twitter.”  The minister was speaking during a three-hour parliamentary debate on the lack of funding for medical research into ME. Politicians called for controversial psychotherapy and exercise therapies recommended by the NHS after a 'flawed' medical trial must stop because it is making patients worse.  They called for an end to stigma and myths surrounding ME. Westminster Hall was told how people with ME are more than six times likely to commit suicide. ME (myalgic encephalomyelitis) affects 250,000 people in the UK, with tens of thousands left bedbound, housebound and unable to work. Sufferers have had to face barbs of laziness and hysteria after the illness was dubbed ‘Yuppie Flu’ in the 1980s. Carol Monaghan (SNP, Glasgow North West) told the debate how ME costs the UK &pound3.3bn per year. She said: “Despite the number of people affected, and the devastating affect this disease has on suffers and indeed, their families, it is very much a hidden illness. “Characterised as ‘yuppie flu’, and misunderstood by doctors and politicians alike, it receives little funding, and treatment is often damaging.”

title: ukips dark arts king lifts
story: NewsUKIP's dark arts king lifts the lid on 14 years with Nigel Farage - Ayes to the Left PodcastThey were branded "fruitcakes". Now UKIP face being something worse - irrelevant. We meet veteran spin doctor Gawain Towler in our Ayes to the Left podcast&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter13:25, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:22, 22 JUN 2018NewsGawain Towler spent 14 years as UKIP's tweed-clad press chief&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDavid Cameron once branded them fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists. Now UKIP face being something much worse - irrelevant. Where next for Nigel Farage's flailing anti-EU party just three years after it won 4million votes - helping push the Leave campaign to victory? Mirror reporters Dan Bloom and Mikey Smith took a party legend to London's Fruit Cake Patisserie to find out. Gawain Towler spent 14 years as UKIP's tweed-clad spin doctor after cleaning toilets in a Knightsbridge club, working on the cheat phone line for video game Worms and modelling for Italian Vogue in Paris. As UKIP's official spokesman, he often found himself defending the indefensible - all in the polite chirpy manner of a Victorian gent.   So we chatted about the party's scandals, its plummeting popularity - and where it goes next. The ex-Territorial Army man confirmed the party's very existence was touch and go earlier this year as it faced bankruptcy. You’ve got those big electronic gadgets that go kthud-kthud-kthud on your chest, he said. Financially it was in huge trouble. People have resigned to help the party survive, he said - and it eventually raised &pound300,000 of salvation cash in six weeks.  But he confirmed he'd often been without an office as UKIP struggled for cash - working out of his living room fielding calls about racist or odd councillors. There are moments when you just sit there and go ‘what’? he said. When you get phoned by some bloke saying ‘er, the Bristol Post is going to have this story about me. You know I’m candidate? I’m also a porn star.' Some cases were eccentric - but some were wildly offensive. One activist said, in the press chief's words, “I cross the road to avoid black people. What the f***? It was truly jaw dropping. Despite staying quiet at the time, Mr Towler admitted he found it very very hard to deal with the racist rant about Meghan Markle by former leader Henry Bolton's girlfriend, Jo Marney.  And speaking of a notorious ex-MEP, he said: I love Godfrey Bloom to pieces but I did have issues with 'Bongo Bongo Land'. Yet Mr Towler blamed a dark campaign by political enemies - including a dossier compiled by Tory central office - for exposing so many UKIP scandals. He defended gay floods man, the councillor who said floods were a punishment for David Cameron railroading through same-sex marriage. I’m merely defending his right to be odd. And he said he agreed with Nigel Farage's hugely divisive admission that he felt awkward hearing foreign languages on public transport. Umm… at times, he said. Not always, generally not, but there are moments where I find things just peculiar. Tolerance is not about agreeing with something, it’s about disagreeing with something and accepting it as part of society. I am tolerant of these things I find uncomfortable. I’m allowed to feel uncomfortable. Must we all feel comfortable because the liberal elite tell me I must feel comfortable? No.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated14:41, 22 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting.  1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland   A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer.  Bike need replacing?       If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90).  And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear.  Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:   Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables   2. The Eden Project, Cornwall      Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination.   Camping out?      Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch.  Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail.   Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.      3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales   The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm.  Why not try..       The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.         4. White Nancy, Cheshire      Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week.  Need to drive?     Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first.  A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.    If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road.   5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland   There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. title: abusive boyfriend made partner massage
story: NewsAbusive boyfriend made partner massage his hands after beating her because injuries ruined his workoutAuzair Hussain, 24, stopped his girlfriend from laughing, told her what she could eat, whipped her with a belt and prevented her from contacting friends and family&nbspShareByPhilip DeweyLucy Clarke-Billings17:11, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:15, 22 JUN 2018NewsHussain was convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH (Image: South Wales Police)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn abusive boyfriend made his partner massage his hands after he beat her because the pain affected his ability to bench press. Auzair Hussain reduced his girlfriend to a shadow of herself during a campaign to control her while they were both students at Cardiff politan University. From January to March last year, 24-year-old Hussain assaulted the French national on numerous occasions and whipped her with a belt and coat hanger. He controlled a number of aspects of his girlfriend’s life including the clothes and make-up she wore, what she ate, when she could shower, and who she was allowed to speak to while he also prevented her from speaking in her mother tongue and from contacting friends and family. He also hated her laughing and made her be quiet when she was in his presence.  A sentencing hearing at Newport Crown Court on Friday heard Hussain first attacked his victim after he saw her smoking a cigarette and she declined to hold his hand in public. It was at this stage he used the belt and hanger to whip his girlfriend, including her chest and private areas. On another occasion, after she looked at a LinkedIn account of a former boyfriend, Hussain threw her about, punched and kicked her, and strangled her before trashing her room. He told his terrified victim – who feared for her life and was so scared she wet herself – he would not hit her in the head because the head is for slapping. After another argument was started by the defendant, he punched and kicked his girlfriend and forced her to strip naked.  Straight after the assault Hussain went to the gym but complained his bench pressing had been affected by hand injuries sustained during the beating. She was later forced to massage his hands to soothe his injuries. Hussain, of Birmingham, was later convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH and he pleaded guilty to a count of assault occasioning ABH. In a statement read out to the court by prosecutor Sarah Waters, his victim said she felt destroyed as a person as a result of the relationship in which she felt trapped. She described the defendant as being extreme in everything he did and of pushing her beyond her boundaries. She said: I think it’s difficult for anyone who has not been in a controlling relationship to understand why I stayed with him but retrospectively I hate myself for being a coward and not running away. What should have been one of the best years of my life studying abroad turned into a nightmare.

title: fiance defends partner after viral
story: NewsFiancée defends partner after viral Facebook post accused him of cheating on her while on lads' holiday to IbizaLucia Ghahramani, 31, says she is angry at the woman who accused her husband-to-be of being a 'love rat'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJessica CrippsNeil Murphy05:59, 22 JUN 2018Updated11:05, 22 JUN 2018NewsLucia Ghahramani says her wedding to partner Jack is still on (Image: Lucia Ghahramani)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The fianc&eacutee of a British holidaymaker accused of cheating on her in a viral Facebook post has jumped to his defence saying he's no love rat.  Lucia Ghahramani has strenuously denied that her husband-to-be Jack Troutt, 23, cheated on her while he was on a lads' holiday to Ibiza. The 31-year-old bride-to-be branded the woman who made the allegation, Steph Kendall, an attention seeker and has confirmed that her wedding to Jack is still on. “I don’t believe the girl. I know Jack and this girl is just attention seeking, she told The Sun. “The wedding is absolutely still on. I was angry, but more at her. Steph says she overheard Troutt bragging to mates that he slept with a woman the previous night and wrote a Facebook post about the conversation.  The post read: If this is your boyfriend Jack staying at the Azuline Bergantin hotel Ibiza him and his friends have been proudly discussing that he cheated on you last night Hun. Troutt says she simply misheard a conversation between his pals about previous relationships while sat around the pool.   The post was taken down by Steph 24 hours after it was published but had already been widely-shared on social media, including by Love Island star Kady McDermott who tweeted it to her 357,000 followers.  Jack, from Essex, has said he now fears for the future of his relationship due to the unwanted attention caused by the post.  It's devastating because I haven't done anything wrong. I haven't had any sexual relations with a woman on this holiday. I haven't kissed another woman or even kissed another woman on the cheek on this holiday. It's literally bizarre.  When he confronted Steph in the hotel to explain she had misheard him, he claims she walked away from him - and the post remained being shared on Facebook .   I tried to confront her and at the same time she just kept walking away from me. I said listen, you've got to get this post down, it's not true. She just walked away. I called her up through Facebook and she just said 'okay hun, bye'. I've got friends and family all contacting me asking me if I'm alright because of the amount of abuse I'm receiving from people all over the country. Jack is bravely speaking out and calling for tougher regulations on social media users accusing people of things that 'ruin their lives with no concrete evidence'. I am sure I am not the first person this has happened to and I know I won't be the last. I think there should be some sort of law or regulation put in place to say how you can make an allegation like that without having anything set in stone. I just think something needs to be put in place where posts like that where you could ruin people's lives without having the concrete evidence. I've reported this post to Facebook a thousand times but they're just not responding. They're just letting it keep getting shared and shared and shared.

title: sas who dares wins star
story: NewsSAS: Who Dares Wins star who heard his wife being stabbed to death is engaged to woman who helped rebuild his lifeDad of two, Dan Cross, whose wife, Nicola, was attacked by a schizophrenic home intruder, will wed mental health clinician Alex Wells next year&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLiz Dunphy10:17, 22 JUN 2018Updated14:02, 22 JUN 2018News&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSAS: Who Dares Wins star Dan Cross who heard his wife being stabbed to death over the phone is engaged to the remarkable woman who has helped rebuild his life. The dad of two, who listened helplessly as wife Nicola was attacked by a schizophrenic home intruder, will wed mental health clinician Alex Wells next year after dating for 15 months.  He said: I'm engaged to Alex. She's a remarkable woman. We're moving forward and hopefully going to get married next year. The children are really happy, he told BBC Three Counties Radio .  Nikki, 37, was brutally killed in September 2015 as she tried to protect her two children Stanley, six, and Isabella, three, from 25-year-old Marcin Porczynski who had broken into their home in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire.  Dan, 40, was at work 200 miles away in Hull when he heard Nicola's screams down the phone as she pleaded for her life before she was stabbed 10 times. Porczynski later pleaded guilty at St Albans Crown Court to Nikki's manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility and was ordered to be detained in a secure psychiatric unit for an indefinite period.   You can listen to Dan's full interview on BBC Three Counties Radio here.    Speaking about finding love with Alex, 27, while dealing with the heartache of losing Nicola, Dan revealed that he has his late wife's blessing explaining: We had that chat. We had discussed what would happen if one of us died young. Nikki said 'I want you to be happy. I want you to find someone else, someone that can look after the kids'. I was the clown and would say 'If I die young, I want you to wear black for the rest of your life and never meet anyone else'. We had the conversation so every day from the day Nikki died decision making was always based around what would Nikki do, what would Nikki want and we still do that today.  Nikki wanted me to be happy. She wanted the children to be happy. She was that type of person and that gives me confidence knowing I'm doing the right thing. I honestly believed for a long time that I would never meet anybody else and then gradually things changed and I began to realise that I didn't want to be on my own for the rest of my life and I knew what Nikki wanted for me. I was worried when I initially thought I was ready to start dating again,'Who would want to now?'   London Marathon cheat who crossed finish line with another runner's number to see a dream come true jailed  This is a guy who is seriously damaged goods, he's got a lot of baggage with him and Alex just takes it all in her stride. She's great with the kids. She's a mental health clinician and knows exactly how to deal with them. They love her to bits. Brave Dan, who following Nicola's death set up the charity Nikki's Wishes to help children who have suffered from bereavement in his late wife's memory, says they will never forget her. Dan added: There will always be that sadness that Nikki is not around. We'll always miss her. We'll always love her. We'll always remember her. We have to keep moving forward as well as holding onto that nice bit of the past. We do, obviously, have our daily issues that we need to address around the event of what happened to Nikki and that will continue, but in general we are a positive family and we'll keep being so.     Dan first revealed he had found love again back in January when he appeared on This Morning. He said: A year ago this weekend I met Alex, she's fitted beautifully into our lives. It's a brave decision to get involved with a family like this, she's a mental health clinician and she can do things with the kids. She does memory boxes where you use your hands and other techniques to bring back memories. It's been amazing, quite freaky really to have someone come in who's so perfect.      Speaking to Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, Dan explained how counselling has helped him and his children to deal with the trauma.  He said: Stanley was six and Isabella was three at the time, I was telling her to leave and go to my mum and dad's but before she could leave he broke through the back doors and killed her. I didn't know what happened to the children until I heard them crying on the phone, and knew they were okay. Dan and his children moved in with his parents after the horrific night, but he returns to his former home sometimes so he can let out his emotions in private and feel closer to Nikki.  Dan underwent trauma counselling afterwards and said he experienced flashbacks within the first month after Nicola died. I felt like I couldn't breathe, I was back in that moment and then I realised if I'm going to be a good dad to the kids and make sure they're confident, happy adults then I need to get help, he said. Viewers of the Channel 4 show SAS: Who Dares Wins were reduced to tears when Dan spoke about how his children motivated him to survive their family tragedy.

title: woman downs syndrome faeces caked
story: NewsWoman with Down's syndrome had 'faeces-caked' catheter left inside her by care home staff before she diedSandra Miller was last pictured celebrating her 55th birthday, but a few months after the image was taken she sadly died in hospital&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByClaire AndersonMichael Yong14:19, 22 JUN 2018NewsThe final photo taken of Sandra as she celebrated her birthday (Image: Bristol Post WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman with Down's syndrome had a dirty catheter left inside her by care home staff before she died. Sandra Miller was last pictured celebrating her 55th birthday with her older sister Lynn Bah, happily sharing cake. But a few months after that photo was taken, Sandra died in hospital. In an investigation report, Dr Martin Plummeridge from Southmead Hospital said nursing staff in the emergency hospital had found her catheter to be “caked in faeces,” Bristol Live reports. It led to a severe infection, with pus-like urine collecting in her bladder. She was diagnosed with sepsis and E.coli Septicaemia which together with pneumonia killed her.  Sandra, who had Down's Syndrome, Type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism and Alzheimer's disease, was in the care of a nursing home for just over a year. But she was rushed to hospital in June 2016 following complications with the catheter fitted by staff at the home. Nurses at the hospital found her catheter blocked and unattached to a bag, leaving it open to the atmosphere and infection. The open end was tucked into her incontinence pad and had become blocked. An investigation found staff had not properly drained the catheter - instead allowing a foul-smelling, pus-like urine to fill her bladder. Sandra died in Southmead Hospital, Bristol, on June 21, 2016, six days after being admitted with the severe urinary tract infection and ultimate heart failure due to sepsis. Her sister Lynn said she felt let down by the staff at Mortimer House. She said: She's had pneumonia before and she's always pulled through. She's a tough bird. It didn't even occur to me that she would die.  I didn't even find out about the catheter problems until she was buried. Finding out about that was even worse. She must have been in absolute agony. They let her down, they failed her. She should be alive and with us now. She was loving and kind, and she had a lovely laugh. We will never hear that again. An investigation found that a consultant urological surgeon had warned about the risk of Sandra's catheter becoming infected in October 2015 - eight months before her death. Milestones Trust, which ran Mortimer House Nursing Home in Kingswood, Bristol, has been ordered by Avon Coroner's Court to make changes and improvements. But 18 months on from Sandra's death, the area manager of Milestones Trust told the coroner she could not confirm whether they had attempted to discontinue the procedure that led to the death. The investigation found Sandra was discharged from hospital in May 2015 to live at Mortimer House Nursing Home.  She had problems going to the toilet due to her disabilities and was fitted with a urinary catheter at the home. It was agreed with her that she would be sedated when the catheter was being changed. But by September, Sandra started to become agitated and would try to remove the urine bag. Consequently, the home had begun to remove the bag and tubing and allow the open catheter to drain freely onto an incontinence pad which Sandra wore. However, a letter from a consultant urological surgeon in October warned nurses that this practice was dangerous, could lead to infections and should not be continued. He recommended instead the use of a flip-flow valve, an alternative to using a urinary drainage bag. Despite the letter being stamped as 'Received' in October 2015, the assistant home manager admitted to court the letter had not been seen by her and colleagues. Mortimer House continued to allow the urinary catheter to drain freely and eight months later, on June 15, 2016, Sandra became unwell and was rushed to Southmead Hospital. An out-of-hours doctor assessed that she might be suffering from sepsis because of pneumonia or urinary tract infection. The Prevention of Future Death report read: The staff nurse in the Emergency Department observed the catheter to not be connected to a bag nor was a spigot fitted. In evidence, the staff nurse stated the tip of the catheter was dirty. On removing the catheter, a large quantity of foul-smelling, pus-like urine drained from the bladder, suggesting the catheter had been blocked. Investigations revealed she was suffering from respiratory and a urinary tract infection and heart failure. She was treated for sepsis, and blood cultures later revealed she had an E-coli septicaemia.
